Rudge
:
<EOS>
a
Tale
of
the
riot
of
'
Eighty
Barnaby
Rudge
 
Charles
Dickens
  
1840
<EOS>
-
-1841
  
<EOS>
information
about
the
source
                   
Chapter
1
    
<EOS>
in
the
year
1775
,
there
stand
upon
the
border
of
Epping
Forest
,
at
a
distance
of
about
twelve
mile
from
London
---
measure
from
the
Standard
in
Cornhill
,
"
or
rather
from
the
spot
on
or
near
to
which
the
Standard
use
to
be
in
day
of
yore
---
a
house
of
public
entertainment
call
the
Maypole
;
which
fact
be
demonstrate
to
all
such
traveller
as
could
neither
read
nor
write
(
and
at
that
time
a
vast
number
both
of
traveller
and
stay
-
at
-
home
be
in
this
condition
)
by
the
emblem
rear
on
the
roadside
over
against
the
house
,
which
,
if
not
of
those
goodly
proportion
that
maypole
be
will
not
to
present
in
olden
time
,
be
a
fair
young
ash
,
thirty
foot
in
height
,
and
straight
as
any
arrow
that
ever
English
yeoman
draw
.
  
<EOS>
the
Maypole
---
by
which
term
from
henceforth
be
mean
the
house
,
and
not
its
sign
---
the
Maypole
be
an
old
building
,
with
more
gable
end
than
a
lazy
man
would
care
to
count
on
a
sunny
day
;
huge
zig
-
zag
chimney
,
out
of
which
it
seem
as
though
even
smoke
could
not
choose
but
come
in
more
than
naturally
fantastic
shape
,
impart
to
it
in
its
tortuous
progress
;
and
vast
stable
,
gloomy
,
ruinous
,
and
empty
.
 
<EOS>
the
place
be
say
to
have
be
build
in
the
day
of
King
Henry
the
Eighth
;
and
there
be
a
legend
,
not
only
that
Queen
Elizabeth
have
sleep
there
one
night
while
upon
a
hunting
excursion
,
to
wit
,
in
a
certain
oak
-
panel
room
with
a
deep
bay
window
,
but
that
next
morning
,
while
stand
on
a
mount
block
before
the
door
with
one
foot
in
the
stirrup
,
the
virgin
monarch
have
then
and
there
box
and
cuff
an
unlucky
page
for
some
neglect
of
duty
.
<EOS>
the
matter
-
of
-
fact
and
doubtful
folk
,
of
whom
there
be
a
few
among
the
Maypole
customer
,
as
unluckily
there
always
be
in
every
little
community
,
be
incline
to
look
upon
this
tradition
as
rather
apocryphal
;
but
,
whenever
the
landlord
of
that
ancient
hostelry
appeal
to
the
mount
block
itself
as
evidence
,
and
triumphantly
point
out
that
there
it
stand
in
the
same
place
to
that
very
day
,
the
doubter
never
fail
to
be
put
down
by
a
large
majority
,
and
all
true
believer
exult
as
in
a
victory
.
  
<EOS>
whether
these
,
and
many
other
story
of
the
like
nature
,
be
true
or
untrue
,
the
Maypole
be
really
an
old
house
,
a
very
old
house
,
perhaps
as
old
as
it
claim
to
be
,
and
perhaps
old
,
which
will
sometimes
happen
with
house
of
an
uncertain
,
as
with
lady
of
a
certain
,
age
.
 
<EOS>
Its
window
be
old
diamond
-
pane
lattice
,
its
floor
be
sink
and
uneven
,
its
ceiling
blacken
by
the
hand
of
time
,
and
heavy
with
massive
beam
.
 
<EOS>
over
the
doorway
be
an
ancient
porch
,
quaintly
and
grotesquely
carve
;
and
here
on
summer
evening
the
more
favoured
customer
smoke
and
drank
---
ay
,
and
sing
many
a
good
song
too
,
sometimes
---
repose
on
two
grim
-
look
high
-
back
settle
,
which
,
like
the
twin
dragon
of
some
fairy
tale
,
guard
the
entrance
to
the
mansion
.
  
<EOS>
in
the
chimney
of
the
disuse
room
,
swallow
have
build
their
nest
for
many
a
long
year
,
and
from
early
spring
to
late
autumn
whole
colony
of
sparrow
chirp
and
twitter
in
the
eave
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
more
pigeon
about
the
dreary
stable
-
yard
and
out
-
building
than
anybody
but
the
landlord
could
reckon
up
.
 
<EOS>
the
wheeling
and
circle
flight
of
runt
,
fantail
,
tumbler
,
and
pouter
,
be
perhaps
not
quite
consistent
with
the
grave
and
sober
character
of
the
building
,
but
the
monotonous
cooing
,
which
never
cease
to
be
raise
by
some
among
them
all
day
long
,
suit
it
exactly
,
and
seem
to
lull
it
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
with
its
overhanging
story
,
drowsy
little
pane
of
glass
,
and
front
bulge
out
and
project
over
the
pathway
,
the
old
house
look
as
if
it
be
nod
in
its
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
indeed
,
it
need
no
very
great
stretch
of
fancy
to
detect
in
it
other
resemblance
to
humanity
.
 
<EOS>
the
brick
of
which
it
be
build
have
originally
be
a
deep
dark
red
,
but
have
grow
yellow
and
discolour
like
an
old
man
's
skin
;
the
sturdy
timber
have
decay
like
tooth
;
and
here
<EOS>
and
there
the
ivy
,
like
a
warm
garment
to
comfort
it
in
its
age
,
wrapt
its
green
leave
closely
round
the
time
-
wear
wall
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
a
hale
and
hearty
age
though
,
still
:
and
in
the
summer
or
autumn
evening
,
when
the
glow
of
the
set
sun
fall
upon
the
oak
and
chestnut
tree
of
the
adjacent
forest
,
the
old
house
,
partaking
of
its
lustre
,
seem
their
fit
companion
,
and
to
have
many
good
year
of
life
in
him
yet
.
  
<EOS>
the
evening
with
which
we
have
to
do
,
be
neither
a
summer
nor
an
autumn
one
,
but
the
twilight
of
a
day
in
March
,
when
the
wind
howl
dismally
among
the
bare
branch
of
the
tree
,
and
rumble
in
the
wide
chimney
and
drive
the
rain
against
the
window
of
the
Maypole
Inn
,
give
such
of
its
frequenter
as
chance
to
be
there
at
the
moment
an
undeniable
reason
for
prolong
their
stay
,
and
cause
the
landlord
to
prophesy
that
the
night
would
certainly
clear
at
eleven
o'clock
precisely
,
---
which
by
a
remarkable
coincidence
be
the
hour
at
which
he
always
close
his
house
.
  
<EOS>
the
name
of
him
upon
whom
the
spirit
of
prophecy
thus
descend
be
John
Willet
,
a
burly
,
large
-
headed
man
with
a
fat
face
,
which
betoken
profound
obstinacy
and
slowness
of
apprehension
,
combine
with
a
very
strong
reliance
upon
his
own
merit
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
John
Willet
's
ordinary
boast
in
his
more
placid
mood
that
if
he
be
slow
he
be
sure
;
which
assertion
could
,
in
one
sense
at
least
,
be
by
no
means
gainsaid
,
see
that
he
be
in
everything
unquestionably
the
reverse
of
fast
,
and
withal
one
of
the
most
dogged
and
positive
fellow
in
existence
---
<EOS>
always
sure
that
what
he
think
or
say
or
do
be
right
,
and
hold
it
as
a
thing
quite
settle
and
ordain
by
the
law
of
nature
and
Providence
,
that
anybody
who
say
or
do
or
think
otherwise
must
be
inevitably
and
of
necessity
wrong
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
walk
slowly
up
to
the
window
,
flatten
his
fat
nose
against
the
cold
glass
,
and
shade
his
eye
that
his
sight
may
not
be
affect
by
the
ruddy
glow
of
the
fire
,
look
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
then
he
walk
slowly
back
to
his
old
seat
in
the
chimney
-
corner
,
and
,
compose
himself
in
it
with
a
slight

,
such
as
a
man
may
give
way
to
<EOS>
and
so
acquire
an
additional
relish
for
the
warm
blaze
,
say
,
look
round
upon
his
guest
:
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
clear
at
eleven
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
no
sooner
and
no
later
.
 
<EOS>
not
before
and
not
arterward
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
how
do
you
make
out
that
?
"
say
a
little
man
in
the
opposite
corner
.
 
<EOS>
"
the
moon
be
past
the
full
,
and
she
rise
at
nine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
look
sedately
and

at
his

until
he
have
bring
his
mind

upon
the

,
and
then

,
in

the
moon
be

his

:
  
<EOS>
"
never

about
the

.
 
<EOS>
do

.
 
<EOS>
You
let
the
moon
alone
,
and
I

you
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
no
offence
I
hope
?
"
say
the
little
man
.
  
<EOS>
again
John
wait
leisurely
until
the
observation
have

to
his

,
and
then

,
"
no

as
yet
,
"
apply

and

;
now

then

at
a
man
wrap
in

with

,

,

,
which
be
still
further
shade
by
the
hand

rest
,
look
unsociable

.
  
<EOS>
there
be
another
guest
,
who
sit
,
boot

,

some

fire

,
and

---
to
judge

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
this
be
a

of
about
eight
-

,

,
and
though
of
somewhat

,
gracefully

.
 
<EOS>
He
wear
his

,

,

together

(
resemble

Life

at

)
,
show

.
 
<EOS>
but
travel
-

though
he
be
<EOS>
,
he
be
well
and

,
and
without
be

look
a

.
  
<EOS>
lie
upon

,
as
he
have
carelessly
throw

down
,
be

and

,
the

no

as
be
best

.
<EOS>
there
,

,
be
a

of

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
little
of
his
face
be
visible
,

which
conceal

,

,
and

which

all

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
towards
this

the

Mr
Willet
wander

,

as

.
 
<EOS>
It

John

have
often

.
 
<EOS>
find

,

,

,

all

,
take

,

stare

.
  
<EOS>
the

have
a

,

)

,

;
<EOS>
but

.
 
<EOS>
no

,

<EOS>
the

become

;

---

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
well
?
"
say

.
  
<EOS>
well
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
not
much
in
well
.
 
<EOS>
It
be

speech
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think

give
an
order
,
"

,
after

.
  
<EOS>
the
stranger
take
off

,
and
disclose
the
hard
feature
of
a
man
of
sixty
or

,
much

and

by

,
and

of

be

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
if

be

to

from

)
as
be

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
"

.

.

!
<EOS>
ha

.

.

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Varden

Miggs
give

,

<EOS>
Chapter
10
    
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
there

present

,

,

.

.

<EOS>
loosely

Chapter

<EOS>

game
away
the
earning
of
the
day
;
or
one
more
weary
than
the
rest
,
give
way
to
sleep
,
and
let
the
fragment
of
his
torch
fall
hiss
on
the
puddle
ground
.
  
<EOS>
then
there
be
the
watch
with
staff
and
lantern
cry
the
hour
,
and
the
kind
of
weather
;
and
those
who
wake
up
at
his
voice
and
turn
them
round
in
bed
,
be
glad
to
hear
it
rain
,
or
snow
,
or
blow
,
or
freeze
,
for
very
comfort
's
sake
.
 
<EOS>
the
solitary
passenger
be
startle
by
the
chairman
's
cry
of
"
by
your
leave
there
!
"
<EOS>
as
two
come
trot
past
him
with
their
empty
vehicle
---
carry
backwards
to
show
its
be
disengage
---
and
hurry
to
the
near
stand
.
<EOS>
many
a
private
chair
,
too
,
inclose
some
fine
lady
,
monstrously
hoop
and
furbelowe
,
and
precede
by
running
-
footman
bear
flambeaux
---
for
which
extinguisher
be
yet
suspend
before
the
door
of
a
few
house
of
the
well
sort
---
make
the
way
gay
and
light
as
it
dance
along
,
and
dark
and
more
dismal
when
it
have
pass
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
not
unusual
for
these
run
gentry
,
who
carry
it
with
a
very
high
hand
,
to
quarrel
in
the
servant
'
hall
while
wait
for
their
master
and
mistress
;
and
,
fall
to
blow
either
there
or
in
the
street
without
,
to
strew
the
place
of
skirmish
with
hair
-
powder
,
fragment
of
bag
-
wig
,
and
scatter
nosegay
.
 
<EOS>
Gaming
,
the
vice
which
run
so
high
among
all
class
(
the
fashion
be
of
course
set
by
the
upper
)
,
be
generally
the
cause
of
these
dispute
;
for
card
and
dice
be
as
openly
use
,
and
work
as
much
mischief
,
and
yield
as
much
excitement
below
stair
,
as
above
.
 
<EOS>
while
incident
like
these
,
arise
out
of
drum
and
masquerade
and
party
at
quadrille
,
be
pass
at
the
west
end
of
the
town
,
heavy
stagecoach
and
scarce
heavy
waggon
be
lumber
slowly
towards
the
city
,
the
coachman
,
guard
,
and
passenger
,
arm
to
the
tooth
,
and
the
coach
---
a
day
or
so
perhaps
behind
its
time
,
but
that
be
nothing
---
despoil
by
highwayman
;
who
make
no
scruple
to
attack
,
alone
and
single
-
handed
,
a
whole
caravan
of
good
and
man
,
and
sometimes
shoot
a
passenger
or
two
,
and
be
sometimes
shoot
themselves
,
as
the
case
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
on
the
morrow
,
rumour
of
this
new
act
of
dare
on
the
road
yield
matter
for
a
few
hour
'
conversation
through
the
town
,
and
a
Public
Progress
of
some
fine
gentleman
(
half
-
drunk
)
to
Tyburn
,
dress
in
the
new
fashion
,
and
damn
the
ordinary
with
unspeakable
gallantry
and
grace
,
furnish
to
the
populace
,
at
once
a
pleasant
excitement
and
a
wholesome
and
profound
example
.
  
<EOS>
among
all
the
dangerous
character
who
,
in
such
a
state
of
society
,
prowl
and
skulk
in
the
metropolis
at
night
,
there
be
one
man
from
whom
many
as
uncouth
and
fierce
as
he
,
shrink
with
an
involuntary
dread
.
 
<EOS>
who
he
be
,
or
<EOS>
whence
he
come
,
be
a
question
often
ask
,
but
which
none
could
answer
.
 
<EOS>
His
name
be
unknown
,
he
have
never
be
see
until
within
about
eight
day
or
thereabout
,
and
be
equally
a
stranger
to
the
old
ruffian
,
upon
whose
haunt
he
venture
fearlessly
,
as
to
the
young
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
be
no
spy
,
for
he
never
remove
his
slouched
hat
to
look
about
him
,
enter
into
conversation
with
no
man
,
heed
nothing
that
pass
,
listen
to
no
discourse
,
regard
nobody
that
come
or
go
.
 
<EOS>
but
so
surely
as
the
dead
of
night
set
in
,
so
surely
this
man
be
in
the
midst
of
the
loose
concourse
in
the
night
-
cellar
where
outcast
of
every
grade
resort
;
and
there
he
sit
till
morning
.
  
<EOS>
He
be
not
only
a
spectre
at
their
licentious
feast
;
a
something
in
the
midst
of
their
revelry
and
riot
that
chill
and
haunt
them
;
but
out
of
door
he
be
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
directly
it
be
dark
,
he
be
abroad
---
never
in
company
with
any
one
,
but
always
alone
;
never
linger
or
loitering
,
but
always
walk
swiftly
;
and
look
(
so
they
say
who
have
see
him
)
over
his
shoulder
from
time
to
time
,
and
as
he
do
so
quicken
his
pace
.
 
<EOS>
in
the
field
,
the
lane
,
the
road
,
in
all
quarter
of
the
town
---
east
,
west
,
north
,
and
south
---
that
man
be
see
glide
on
like
a
shadow
.
 
<EOS>
He
be
always
hurry
away
.
 
<EOS>
those
who
encounter
him
,
see
him
steal
past
,
catch
sight
of
the
backward
glance
,
and
so
lose
him
in
the
darkness
.
  
<EOS>
this
constant
restlessness
,
and
flit
to
and
fro
,
give
rise
to
strange
story
.
 
<EOS>
He
be
see
in
such
distant
and
remote
place
,
at
time
so
nearly
tally
with
each
other
,
that
some
doubt
whether
there
be
not
two
of
them
,
or
more
---
some
,
whether
he
have
not
unearthly
mean
of
travel
from
spot
to

.
 
<EOS>
the
footpad
hide
in
a
ditch
have
mark
him
pass
like
a
ghost
along
its

;
the
vagrant
have
meet

on
the
dark
high
-
road
;
the

have
see

pause
upon

,
and

sweep

;
they
who
deal
in
body

sleep

,
and
that

behold

.
 
<EOS>
and
as

these
story
to

,
one
who
have
look
about

would
pull
his
neighbour
by

,
and
there
he
would
be
among
them
.
  
<EOS>
at
last
,
one
man
---
he
be
one
of
those
whose
commerce
lie
among
the
grave
---
resolve
to
question
this
strange

.
 
<EOS>
next
night
,
when
he
have
eat
his
poor

(
he
be

,
they
have
observe
,
as

have
no

)
,
this

sit

.
  
<EOS>
"
a
black
night
,
master
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
be
a
black
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Blacker
than
last
,
though
that
be
pitchy

.
 
<EOS>
do
not
I
pass

near
the

in
the
Oxford

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
be
like
you
may
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

,

,
"
cry

fellow
,
urge

by

,
and
slap

;
"
be
more

.
 
<EOS>
be
more
the

this
good

.
 
<EOS>
there
be
tale
among

that
you
have
sell

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,

?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
if

be
few

,
perhaps
he

well
wage
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
go

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
be

,

.
 
<EOS>
a

of
a

now
"
---
   
<EOS>
"
sing

,

,
"
reply

,

;
"

arm
which

---

---

do

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"
return

,
rise

upon

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
His

,

,

---
all

of

and

---
daunt

.
 
<EOS>
although

of

,
they
be

of

have
work

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
be

,

,
"
say

man

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
in
hide
here
like

,
and
if
we
be
surprised
<EOS>
would
perhaps

my

with

.
 
<EOS>
if

to
be

,

.
 
<EOS>
otherwise
,
"
---
and

he
swear

---
"
there

mischief
do
in
this

,
though
there
are
odd
of

score
against

.
"
  
<EOS>
a
low

,
have
its

in
a

of
the
man
and

that

,

,

if

,
warn

have
occasion

that
he
have
good

.
 
<EOS>
after

the

man
lie

upon
a

,
and
when

,
they
find
he
be
go
.
  
<EOS>
next
night
,
as

it
be

,
he
be
abroad
again
and
traverse
the
street
;
he
be
before
the
locksmith
's
house
more
than

,
but
the
family
be
out
,
and
it
be
close

.
 
<EOS>
this
night
he
cross
London
Bridge
and
pass
into
Southwark
.
 
<EOS>
as
he
glide
down
a
bye
street
,
a
woman
with
a

on
her

,
turn
into
it

other

.
 
<EOS>
directly
he
observe
her
,
he
seek
the

of
an

,
and
stand

until
she
have
pass
.
 
<EOS>
then
he
emerge

from
his

-
place
,
and
follow
.
  
<EOS>
She
go
into
several
shop
to
purchase
various
kind
of
household
necessary
,
and
round
every
place
at
which
she
stop
he
hover
like
her
evil
spirit
;
follow

when
she

.
 
<EOS>
It
be
nigh

,
and
the
passenger
in
the
street
be
thin
fast
,
when
she
turn
,
doubtless
to

.
 
<EOS>
the
phantom
still
follow
her
.
  
<EOS>
She
turn
into

same
bye
street
in
which
he
have
see
her

,
which
,
be
free
from
shop
,
and
narrow
,
be

.
 
<EOS>
She
quicken

here
,
as
though

of
be
stop
,
and
rob

such

as
she

.
 
<EOS>
He
creep
along
on
the
other

.
 
<EOS>
have
she
be
gift
with
the
speed
of
wind
<EOS>
,
it
seem
as
if
his
terrible
shadow
would
have
track
her
down
.
  
<EOS>
at
length
the
widow
---
for
she
it
be
---
reach
her

door
,
and
,
pant
for

,
pause
to
take
the
key
from
her

.
 
<EOS>
in
a

and

,
with
the

she
have

,

the

of
be
safe

,
she

,

,
raise

,
she
see

stand

:
<EOS>
the
apparition
of
a

.
  
<EOS>
His

be
on

,
but

be

,
for
her

clove
to

,
and
her

be
go
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
be
look

.
 
<EOS>
be

?
 
<EOS>
answer

.
<EOS>
be

?
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
He
take
the
key
,
unlock

,
carry

in
,
and
secure

behind

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
17
    
<EOS>
It
be
a
chilly
night
,
and
the
fire
in
the
widow
's
parlour
have
burn
low
.
 
<EOS>
Her
strange
companion
place
her
in
a
chair
,
and
stoop
down
before
the
half
-
extinguish
ashe
,
rake
them
together
and
fan
them
with
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
from
time
to
time
he
glance
at
her
over
his
shoulder
,
as
though
to
assure
himself
of
her
remain
quiet
and
make
no
effort
to
depart
;
and
that
do
,
busy
himself
about
the
fire
again
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
not
without
reason
that
he
take
these
pain
,
for
his
dress
be
dank
and
drench
with
wet
,
his
jaw
rattle
with
cold
,
and
he
shiver
from
head
to
foot
.
 
<EOS>
It
have
rain
hard
during
the
previous
night
and
for
some
hour
in
the
morning
,
but
since
noon
it
have
be
fine
.
 
<EOS>
Wheresoever
he
have
pass
the
hour
of
darkness
,
his
condition
sufficiently
betoken
that
many
of
them
have
be
spend
beneath
the
open
sky
.
 
<EOS>
besmear
with
mire
;
his
saturate
clothe
cling
with
a
damp
embrace
about
his
limb
;
his
beard
unshaven
,
his
face
unwashed
,
his
meagre
cheek
wear
into
deep
hollow
,
---
a
more
miserable
wretch
could
hardly
be
,
than
this
man
who
now
cower
down
upon
the
widow
's
hearth
,
and
watch
the
struggle
flame
with
bloodshot
eye
.
  
<EOS>
She
have
cover
her
face
with
her
hand
,
fear
,
as
it
seem
,
to
look
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
so
they
remain
for
some
short
time
in
silence
.
<EOS>
glance
round
again
,
he
ask
at
length
:
  
"
be
this
your
house
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
be
.
 
<EOS>
why
,
in
the
name
of
Heaven
,
do
you
darken
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
give
me
meat
and
drink
,
"
he
answer
sullenly
,
"
or
I
dare
do
more
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
the
very
marrow
in
my
bone
be
cold
,
with
wet
and
hunger
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
warmth
and
food
,
and
I
will
have
them
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
be
the
robber
on
the
Chigwell
road
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
be
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
and
nearly
a
murderer
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
the
will
be
not
want
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
one
come
upon
me
and
raise
the
hue
-
and
-
cry
'
,
that
it
would
have
go
hard
with
,
but
for
his
nimbleness
.
 
<EOS>
I
make
a
thrust
at
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
thrust
your
sword
at
him
!
"
<EOS>
cry
the
widow
,
look
upwards
.
<EOS>
"
You
hear
this
man
!
<EOS>
you
hear
and
see
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
look
at
her
,
as
,
with
her

throw

,
and
her

,
she
utter
these
word
in

.
 
<EOS>
then
,
start
to
his

as
she
have

,
he

towards
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
beware
!
"
<EOS>
she
cry
in
a

,
whose

stop
him

.
 
<EOS>
"
do
not
so
much
as
touch
me
with

,
or
you
be
lose
;
body
and

,
you
be
lose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
hear
me
,
"
he
reply
,
menace
her
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
,
that
in
the
form
of
a
man
live
the
life
of
a
hunt
beast
<EOS>
;
that
in
the
body
be
a
spirit
,
a
ghost
upon
the
earth
,
a

from

all
creature
shrink
,
save
those
curst
being
of
another

,
who
will

;
---
I
be
,
in

of
this
night
,
past
all
fear
but
that
of
the
hell
in
which
I
exist
from
day
to

.
 
<EOS>
give
the
alarm
,
cry
out
,
refuse
to
shelter
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
hurt
you
.
 
<EOS>
but
I
will
not
be
take
alive
;
and
so
surely
as
you
threaten
me
above
your
breath
,
I
fall
a
dead
man
on
this
floor
.
 
<EOS>
the
blood
with
which
I
sprinkle
it
,
be
on
you
and
yours
,
in
the
name
of
the
Evil
Spirit
that
tempt
man
to
their
ruin
!
"
  
<EOS>
as
he
speak
,
he
take
a
pistol
from
his
breast
,
and
firmly
clutch
it
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
remove
this

from

,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
in
thy

and

,
give

's

,

strike

dead
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
have
no
such
purpose
,
"
he
say
,
confront

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
be
deaf
.
<EOS>
give

to
eat
and
drink
,
lest
I
do
that
it
can
not
help
my
doing
,
and
will

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
leave
me
,
if
I
do
thus

?
 
<EOS>
Will

leave
me
and
return

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will

nothing
,
"
he

,
seat

the
table
,
"
nothing
but
this
<EOS>
---
I
will
execute
my
threat
if
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
rise
at
length
,
and
go
to
a

in

,
bring

some

.
 
<EOS>
He
ask
for
brandy
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
these
she
produce
likewise
;
and
he
eat
and
drink
with

of
a
famish

.
 
<EOS>
all

he
be
so
engaged
she
keep
at
the
uttermost

of
the

,
and
sit
there
shudder
,
<EOS>
but
with
her

towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
turn

upon
him
once
;
and
although
when

pass

(
as

be

)
<EOS>
she
gather
the

her

,

its
touch
his
by
chance
be
horrible

,

,

this
dread
and

,
she
keep
her
face
towards
his
own
,
and
watch

every

.
  
<EOS>
His
repast
end
---
if
that

call

,

be

of

---

,

warm

before
the

which
have

,
accost

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
be
an
outcast
,
to

a
roof
above
his
head
be
often
an
uncommon
luxury
,
and
the
food
a

would
reject
be

.
 
<EOS>
You
live
here

.
 
<EOS>
do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,
"
she

<EOS>
"
who

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
one
---

.
 
<EOS>

good
begone
,

.
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
for

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

.

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Begone
.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
much

<EOS>
miserable

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
that

!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>

have

,

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

?
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>

spring

in

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
be
afield
,

---

,

,

,
up

.
<EOS>
the

have
be

,

plant

,
lest

,
the

---
and
Grip
---
ha
ha
ha
!
---
<EOS>
brave
Grip
,
who

nothing
,
and
when

,

---
grip
,
bold
Grip
,
have

with
every

---
thinking
,
he
tell

,
that

---

have
worry
it
like

.
<EOS>
ha

!
"
  
<EOS>
the
raven
,
in

at

's

,
hear

in

,

by

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
such

,

!
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
the

crow

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

to
-

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
We
have

,

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
anxious

,

<EOS>
the
listener
hold

,

.
 
<EOS>
Grip
---
alive

his

be

---
 
have

,
and
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

,

,
"
as

stranger

,

.
 
<EOS>
Jump

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
accept

,
the

,
from

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
believe
,
no

have

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
say

,

,

have

,
"
I

-

,

,
---

?
"
  
<EOS>
She
take

in
hers
,

,
nod
the
word
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
tell

<EOS>
You
have
anticipate
it
for
year
;
you
have
tell
me
as
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
leave
you
to
digest
it
.
 
<EOS>
do
not
forget
my
warning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
point
,
as
he
leave
her
,
to
the

form
,
and
stealthily

,
make

.
 
<EOS>
She
fall
on

the

,
and

into
stone
,
until

which
fear

,
come

.
  
<EOS>
"
oh

,
"
she

,
"
who
hast

such

for
this

of
the

,
out

,
even

comfort
spring
that
he
be
ever
a

love

,

,

!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
18
    
glide
along
the
silent
street
,
and
hold
his
course
where
they
be
dark
and
most
gloomy
,
the
man
who
have
leave

widow

cross

,
and
arrive
in
the
City
,
plunge
into
the

,

,

,
between

;
with
no

than
to

among
their

,
and
baffle

,
if
any

be
dog
his
step
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
the
dead
time
of
the
night
,
and
all
be
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
now
<EOS>
and
then
a
drowsy
watchman
's
footstep
sound
on

,
or
the

on

round

,
leave

mingle

.
 
<EOS>
He
hide
himself
even
from
these
partaker
of
his
lonely

,
and
,
shrink
in
some
arch

while
they
pass
,
issue
forth

when
they
be
go
and
so

.
  
<EOS>
to
be

in

,

moan
and
watch
for

through
the
whole

;
to

,
and

,

;
be

---
but
not

as
the

up

down
where
shelter
be
,
and
bed
and

be
by

;
a

reject
creature
.
 
<EOS>
to
pace
the
echo
stone
from
hour
to

,
count

dull

of
the
clock
;
to
watch
the
light
twinkle
in
chamber
window
,
to
think
what
happy
forgetfulness
each
house
shut
in
;
that
here
be
child
coil

in

,
here
youth
,
here

,
here

,
here

,

,

;
to

,
not

,
Heaven
's

to

,
and
be

nothing

;
to

,
by

with

,

than
in
a

;
this
be
a
kind

,
on
which
the
river
of
great
city
close
full
many
a

,
and
which
the

in

alone

.
  
<EOS>
the
miserable
man
pace
up
and
down
the
street
---
so
long
,
so

,
<EOS>
so
like

---
and
often

,
hope

.
<EOS>
but
obdurate
night
have
yet

of

,
and
his

find

.
  
<EOS>
one

in

be

;

,

,

cheerful

,

.
 
<EOS>
to

---

that
be

---
he
return

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

;
and

be

,

.
  
<EOS>
His

bring

at

.
 
<EOS>

ill

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

be

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
He
be

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

!

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>
Chapter
29
    
<EOS>
the
thought
of
worldly
man
be
for
ever
regulate
by
a
moral
law
of
gravitation
,
which
,
like
the
physical
one
,
hold
them
down
to
earth
.
 
<EOS>
the
bright
glory
of
day
,
and
the
silent
wonder
of
a
starlit
night
<EOS>
,
appeal
to
their
mind
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
no
sign
in
the
sun
,
or
in
the
moon
,
or
in
the
star
,
for
their
reading
.
<EOS>
They
be
like
some
wise
man
,
who
,
learn
to
know
each
planet
by
its
latin
name
,
have
quite
forget
such
small
heavenly
constellation
as
Charity
,
Forbearance
,
Universal
Love
,
and
mercy
,
although
they
shine
by
night
and
day
so
brightly
that
the
blind
may
see
them
;
and
who
,
look
upward
at
the
spangle
sky
,
see
nothing
there
<EOS>
but
the
reflection
of
their
own
great
wisdom
and
book
-
learning
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
curious
to
imagine
these
people
of
the
world
,
busy
in
thought
,
turn
their
eye
towards
the
countless
sphere
that
shine
above
us
,
and
make
them
reflect
the
only
image
their
mind
contain
.
 
<EOS>
the
man
who
live
<EOS>
but
in
the
breath
of
prince
,
have
nothing
his
sight
but
star
for
courtier
'
breast
.
 
<EOS>
the
envious
man
behold
his
neighbour
'
honour
even
in
the
sky
;
to
the
money
-
hoarder
,
and
the
mass
of
worldly
folk
,
the
whole
great
universe
above
glitter
with
sterling
coin
---
fresh
from
the
mint
---
stamp
with
the
sovereign
's
head
---
come
always
between
them
and
heaven
,
turn
where
they
may
.
 
<EOS>
so
do
the
shadow
of
our
own
desire
stand
between
us
and
our
well
angel
,
and
thus
their
brightness
be
eclipse
.
  
<EOS>
everything
be
fresh
and
gay
,
as
though
the
world
be
but
that
morning
make
,
when
Mr
Chester
ride
at
a
tranquil
pace
along
the
Forest
road
.
 
<EOS>
though
early
in
the
season
,
it
be
warm
and
genial
weather
;
the
tree
be
bud
into
leaf
,
the

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
31
    
ponder

<EOS>
Chapter
33
    
<EOS>
one

,
early

the

our
Lord
one

seven

,
<EOS>

arise

grow

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
a

,

and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Signboards
,
shake
past
endurance
in

,

;
old

;
and
many

that

as

be

.
  
<EOS>

be

<EOS>
in

<EOS>
each

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
cheerily

<EOS>

the
light
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
enter

,
and

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
35
    
when
John
Willet
see

,

;

be

.
 
<EOS>
by

,

!

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
no
,

,

;

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
a

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

its

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>

---

---

.
 
<EOS>
no

.
 
<EOS>
let
John
Grueby
pass

---

.
 
<EOS>
but

)

;

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
amen
.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

,

?
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

,

brow

gloom
and
shadow
,
stalk

---
<EOS>
"
  
"
oh
,

,
"
cie

"

use

,
under
such

,

's

,

?
 
<EOS>

---

<EOS>
"

;

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

---

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
the

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Gashford
,

,
be
tall

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

WOULDN'T

;

.

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
37
    
to
surround
anything
,
however
monstrous
or

,
with

,
be
to
invest

with

,
and
power

which
to

.
 
<EOS>
false

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

be
,
and
have
be
from
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
to

,

by

,

,

can
be
have
,

wrong
,

.
  
<EOS>

have
stand

,
call

,

-

,

Gordon
,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

Dance
.
    
<EOS>
chapter
39
    
<EOS>
the
applause
which
the
performance
of
Hugh
and
his
new
friend
elicit
from
the
company
at
the
Boot
,
have
not
yet
subside
,
and
the
two
dancer
be
still
pant
from
their
exertion
,
which
have
be
of
a
rather
extreme
and
violent
character
,
when
the
party
be
reinforce
by
the
arrival
of
some
more
guest
,
who
,
be
a
detachment
of
United
Bulldogs
,
be
receive
with
very
flattering
mark
of
distinction
and
respect
.
  
<EOS>
the
leader
of
this
small
party
---
for
,
include
himself
,
they
be
but
three
in
number
---
be
our
old
acquaintance
,
Mr
Tappertit
,
who
seem
,
physically
speak
,
to
have
grow
small
with
year
(
particularly
as
to
his
leg
,
which
be
stupendously
little
)
,
but
who
,
in
a
moral
point
of
view
,
in
personal
dignity
and
self
-
esteem
,
have
swell
into
a
giant
.
 
<EOS>
nor
be
it
by
any
mean
difficult
for
the
most
unobservant
person
to
detect
this
state
of
feeling
in
the
quondam
'
prentice
,
for
it
not
only
proclaim
itself
impressively
and
beyond
mistake
in
his
majestic
walk
and
kindle
eye
,
but
find
a
striking
mean
of
revelation
in
his
turn
-
up
nose
,
which
scout
all
thing
of
earth
with
deep
disdain
,
and
seek
communion
with
its
kindred
sky
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
,
as
chief
or
captain
of
the
Bulldogs
,
be
attend
by
his
two
lieutenant
;
one
,
the
tall
comrade
of
his
young
life
;
the
other
,
a
'
Prentice
Knight
in
day
of
yore
---
Mark
Gilbert
,
bind
in
the
olden
time
to
Thomas
Curzon
of
the
Golden
Fleece
.
 
<EOS>
these
gentleman
,
like
himself
,
be
now
emancipate
from
their
'
prentice
thraldom
,
and
serve
as
journeyman
;
but
they
be
,
in
humble
emulation
of
his
great
example
,
bold
and
daring
spirit
,
and
aspire
to
a
distinguished
state
in
great
political
event
.
 
<EOS>
hence
their
connection
with
the
Protestant
Association
of
England
,
sanction
by
the
name
of
Lord
George
Gordon
;
and
hence
their
present
visit
to
the
Boot
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
!
"
say
Mr
Tappertit
,
take
off

hat
as
a

general
may
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
well
meet
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
do
me
and

the

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
see
my
lord

,

?
"
say

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see

this

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

,

,
"

reply
,

.
 
<EOS>
"

do

do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
lively
,
master
,
lively
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
here
be
a
new
brother
,
regularly

down
in
black

by
Muster
Gashford
;
a

;
one

stick
-

;

arter

.
 
<EOS>
d'ye

?
 
<EOS>
have

will
do
,

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
look

,
"

,

,
"
I
be

.
 
<EOS>
I
hate

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

me
<EOS>
and

.
 
<EOS>
They

can
,
and
I

can
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
be
there
ever
,
"
say
Dennis
,
look

,
when

bad

;
"
be
there
ever
such

game
boy
!
 
<EOS>
why
,

mean

,

,

if
Muster

have
go

and

fifty
man

,

be
worth

.
"
  
<EOS>
the
great

implicitly
subscribe
to
this
opinion
,
and
testify

faith
in
Hugh
by

and

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
sit
and
contemplate
him
for
a
long

,
as

suspend

;

draw

,

;
then

close

,

apart

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
he

,

,
"

before
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
be
like
you
may
,
"
say
Hugh
,
in
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
;
should
not
wonder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
no
,
<EOS>
but
it
be

settle
,
"
return
Sim
.
 
<EOS>
"
look

.
<EOS>
do

?
 
<EOS>

would

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
do

;
I

.
 
<EOS>
take
a
good
look
---
steady

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
the

way

Mr
Tappertit
make

,

with

he
nee

,

Hugh
mightily

,

see
nothing

of
the

,
through
close

,

great

.
  
<EOS>
"
come
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
laugh
again
,
and
with
such
thorough

to
his
mad

,
that
his

seem
dislocate
,
and
his
whole
frame
in
danger
of
tumble
to
piece
;
but
Mr
Tappertit
,
so
far

receive
this

with
any

,
be
pleased
to
regard

with
the
utmost

,
and
even

,
so
far
as
one
of
his
gravity
and
station
could
,
with
any
regard
to
that
decency
and
decorum
which
man
in
high
place
be
expect
to
maintain
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
do
not
stop
here
,
as
many
public
character
may
have
do
,
but
call
up
his
brace
of
lieutenant
,
introduce
Hugh
to
them
with
high
commendation
;
declare
him
to
be
a
man
who
,
at
such
time
as
those
in
which
they
live
,
could
not
be
too
much
cherish
.
 
<EOS>
further
,
he
do
him
the
honour
to
remark
,
that
he
would
be
an
acquisition
of
which
even
the
United
Bulldogs
may
be
proud
;
and
finding
,
upon
sound
him
,
that
he
be
quite
ready
and
willing
to
enter
the
society
(
for
he
be
not
at
all

,
and
would
have
league
himself
that
night
with
anything
,
or
anybody
,
for
any

whatsoever
)
,
cause
the
necessary
preliminary
to
be
go
into
upon

spot
.
 
<EOS>
this
tribute
to
his
great
merit
delight
no
man
more
than
Mr
Dennis
,
as
he
himself
proclaim
with
several
rare
and
surprising
oath
;
and
indeed
it
give
unmingle
satisfaction
to
the
whole
assembly
.
  
<EOS>
"
make
anything
you
like
of
me
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Hugh
,
flourish
the
can
he
have
empty
more
than
once
.
 
<EOS>
"
put
me
on
any
duty
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
be
your
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
here
be
my
captain
---
here
be
my
leader
.
 
<EOS>
ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
let
him
give
me
the
word
of
command
,
and
I
will
fight
the
whole
Parliament
House
single
-
handed
,
or
set
a
light
torch
to
the
King
's
throne
itself
!
"
 
<EOS>
with
that
,
he
smite
Mr
Tappertit
on
the
back
,
with
such
violence
that
his
little
body
seem
to
shrink
into
a
mere
nothing
;
and
roar
again
until
the
very
foundling
near
at
hand
be
startle
in
their
bed
.
  
<EOS>
in
fact
,
a
sense
of
something
whimsical
in
their
companionship
seem
to
have
take
entire
possession
of
his
rude
brain
.
 
<EOS>
the
bare
fact
of
be
patronise
by
a
great
man
whom
he
could
have
crush
with
one
hand
,
appear
in
his
eye
so
eccentric
and
humorous
,
that
a
kind
of
ferocious
merriment
gain
the
mastery
over
him
,
and
quite
subdue
his
brutal
nature
.
 
<EOS>
He
roar
and
roar
again
;
toast
Mr
Tappertit
a
hundred
time
;
declare
himself
a
Bulldog
to
the
core
;
and
vow
to
be
faithful
to
him
to
the
last
drop
of
blood
in
his
vein
.
  
<EOS>
all
these
compliment
Mr
Tappertit
receive
as
matter
of
course
---
 
flattering
enough
in
their
way
,
but
entirely
attributable
to
his
vast
superiority
.
 
<EOS>
His
dignified
self
-
possession
only
delight
Hugh
the
more
;
and
in
a
word
,
this
giant
and
dwarf
strike
up
a
friendship
which
bid
fair
to
be
of
long
continuance
,
as
the
one
hold
it
to
be
his
right
to
command
,
and
the
other
consider
it
an
exquisite
pleasantry
to
obey
.
 
<EOS>
nor
be
Hugh
by
any
mean
a
passive
follower
,
who
scruple
to
act
without
precise
and
definite
order
;
for
when
Mr
Tappertit
mount
on
an
empty
cask
which
stand
by
way
of
rostrum
in
the
room
,
and
volunteer
a
speech
upon
the
alarm
crisis
then
at
hand
,
he
place
himself
beside
the
orator
,
and
though
he
grin
from
ear
to
ear
at
every
word
he
say
,
throw
out
such
expressive
hint
to
scoffer
in
the
management
of
his
cudgel
,
that
those
who
be
at
first
the
most
disposed
to
interrupt
,
become
remarkably
attentive
,
and
be
the
loud
in
their
approbation
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
not
all
noise
and
jest
,
however
,
at
the
Boot
,
nor
be
the
whole
party
listener
to
the
speech
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
some
man
at
the
other
end
of
the
room
(
which
be
a
long
,
low
-
roof
chamber
)
in

<EOS>
Chapter
42
    
<EOS>

reason

actual
occurrence
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
the
furniture
remain
in
Mrs
Rudge
's
house
,
and
that
it
have
be
shut
up
,
by
my

,
since
she
go

,
save
once

-
week

,
when
an

visit

to

.
 
<EOS>
I
be
on
my
way
there
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
for
what
purpose
?
"
ask
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
to
pass
the
night
there
,
"
he
reply
;
"
and
not

-
night

,

.
 
<EOS>
this

which
I
trust

you

.
 
<EOS>
You
will
not

,
unless
in

strong

,
to
me
;
from
dusk

I

.
 
<EOS>
Emma
,
your

,

,
suppose

out

London
,
as

have
be
until
within
this

.
 
<EOS>
do

.
 
<EOS>
this
be
the
errand
I
be
bind
upon
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
I
may
confide

to

,
and
I

upon
your

.
"
  
<EOS>
with

,
as

,

lead

astounded
locksmith
back
to
the
night
of
the
Maypole

,
to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
even
ask

's

,

,

---

,

---

,

,

express

,

.
  
<EOS>
at

,

stand
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

,
"
he

,

,
"
you
can
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
,

former
marvel
have
be
nothing

this
,
follow

.
 
<EOS>
when

,
Mr

softly

he
have
about

,
and
close

when
Varden
enter
,
they
be
leave

.
  
<EOS>
They
grope
their

into
the
ground
-
floor
room
.
 
<EOS>
here
Mr
Haredale
strike
a
light
,
and

a
pocket

he
have
bring
with

for

.
 
<EOS>
It
be

,

be

,
that

see

how

,

,
and

;

;

that

have
say

.
 
<EOS>
It
be
not
an

in
Gabriel
,

what

have

,
to
note

.
 
<EOS>
It
be
perfectly
collect

;
---
 
so
much
<EOS>

,

,
that
he
feel

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will

through

?
"
say

Haredale
,
with

,
the
crazy

of

be
close

.
 
<EOS>
"
speak
low
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
there
be
a
kind

awe
about

place
,
which
would
have
render

difficult
to

.
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
whisper
"
yes
,
"
and
follow

.
  
<EOS>
everything
be
just
as
they
have
see

.
 
<EOS>
there
be
a

from
the

of

,
and

around
,
as

have

.
 
<EOS>
the

of

have

;
the

upon

dwindle

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
the

,

;
nimble

,

's

,

,

;

;

.
  
<EOS>

,

present

,

.
 
<EOS>
Grip

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

in

.
  
<EOS>
They

,
and
again
into

room
they

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
unbuckle

,
with
a

of
pocket

;
then
tell

he
would

.
  
<EOS>
"
but

be

,

,
"

;
"
may

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
in

be

,

see
that

once

,
and
soon

to

,
shine

.
  
<EOS>
if
ever
man
be
sorely
puzzle
and

,
the

be
,
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
even
when
snugly
seat

,

,

)

,

---

,

,

<EOS>
(

)

,

.
<EOS>
so

---

,

until
the

should

and

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
43
    
<EOS>
Next
morning
bring
no
satisfaction
to
the
locksmith
's
thought
,
nor
next
day
,
nor
the
next
,
nor
many
other
.
 
<EOS>
often
after
nightfall
he
enter
the
street
,
and
turn
his
eye
towards
the
well
-
know
house
;
and
as
surely
as
he
do
so
,
there
be
the
solitary
light
,
still
gleam
through
the
crevice
of
the
window
-
shutter
,
while
all
within
be
motionless
,
noiseless
,
cheerless
,
as
a
grave
.
<EOS>
unwilling
to
hazard
Mr
Haredale
's

by
disobey
his
strict
injunction
,
he
never
venture
to
knock

the

or

make

know
in
any
way
.
 
<EOS>
but
whenever
strong
interest
and

attract

to
the

---
which
be
not
seldom
---
the
light
be
always
there
.
  
<EOS>
if
he
could
have
know
what
pass
within
,
the
knowledge
would
have
yield
him
no

to
this

.
 
<EOS>
at
twilight
,
Mr
Haredale
shut
himself
up
,
and
at
daybreak
he
come
forth
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
miss
a
night
,
always
come
and
go
alone
,
and
never
vary
his
proceeding
in
the
least
degree
.
  
<EOS>
the
manner
of
his
watch
be
this
.
 
<EOS>
at
dusk
,
he
enter
the
house
in
the
same
way
as
when
the
locksmith
bear
him
company
,
kindle

,
go
through

room
,
and
narrowly

.
 
<EOS>
that
do
,
he
return
to
the
chamber
on
the
ground
-
floor
,
and
lay
his
sword
and
pistol
on
the
table
,
sit
by
it
until
morning
.
  
<EOS>
He
usually
have
a
book
with
him
,
and
often
try
to
read
,
but
never
fix
his
eye
or
thought
upon

for
five
minute

.
 
<EOS>
the
slight
noise
without
door
,
catch
his
ear
;
a
step
upon
the
pavement
seem
to
make
his
heart
leap
.
  
<EOS>
He
be
not
without
some
refreshment
during
the
long

;
generally
carry
in

pocket
a
sandwich
of
bread
and

,
and
a

of

.
 
<EOS>
the
latter
dilute
with
large
quantity
of
water
,
he
drink
in
a
heated
,
feverish
way
,
as

his

be
dry
;
but
he
scarcely
ever
break
his

,
by
so
much

bread
.
  
<EOS>
if
this
voluntary

of
sleep
and

have
its
origin
,
as
the
locksmith
on
consideration
be
dispose
to
think
,
in
any

of
the

of
a

connect
with
the
event
on
which
he
have
brood
for
so
many

,
and
if
he
wait
for
some

who
walk

when
man
lie
sleep
in
their
bed
,
he
show
no
trace
of
fear
or

.
 
<EOS>
His
stern
feature
express
inflexible
resolution
;
his
brow
be
pucker
,
and
his

compress
,
with
deep
and

purpose
;
and
when

start

and

,

be
not
with
the

of
fear
but
hope
,
and
catch

as

have
come

,

would

in

,
and
listen
with

and

,
until
it
die

.
  
<EOS>
these
disappointment
be
numerous
,
for
they
ensue
on
almost
every
sound
,
but
his
constancy
be
not

.
 
<EOS>
still
,
every
night
he
be
at
his
post
,
the
same
stern
,
sleepless
,
sentinel
;
and
still
night
pass
,
and
morning
dawn
,
and
he
must
watch
again
.
  
<EOS>
this
go
on
for
week
;
he
have
take
a
lodging
at
Vauxhall
in
which
to
pass
the
day
and
rest
himself
;
and
from
this
place
,
when
the
tide
serve
,
he
usually
come
to
London
Bridge
from
Westminster
by
water
,
in
order
that
he
may
avoid
the
busy
street
.
  
<EOS>
one
evening
,
shortly
before
twilight
,
he
come
his
accustomed
road
upon
the
river
's
bank
,
intend
to
pass
through
Westminster
Hall
into
Palace
Yard
,
and
there
take
boat
to
London
Bridge
as
usual
.
<EOS>
there
be
a
pretty
large
concourse
of
people
assemble
round
the
Houses
of
Parliament
,
look
at
the
member
as
they
enter
and

,
and
give
vent
to
rather
noisy

of
approval
or

,
accord
to
their
know

.
 
<EOS>
as
he
make
his
way
among
the
throng
,
he
hear
once
or
twice
the
no
-
popery
cry
,
which
be
then
become
pretty
familiar
to
the
ear
of
most
man
;
but
hold
it
in
very
slight
regard
,
and
observe
that
the
idler
be
of
the
low
grade
,
he
neither
think
nor
care
about
it
,
but
make
his
way
along
,
with
perfect
indifference
.
  
<EOS>
there
be
many
little
knot
and
group
of
person
in
Westminster
Hall
:
some
few
look
upward
at
its
noble
ceiling
,
and
at
the
ray
of
evening
light
,
tint
by
the
set
sun
,
which
stream
in
aslant
through
its
small

,
and
grow

by
degree
,
be
quench
in
the
gathering

below
;
some
,
noisy
passenger
,
mechanic
go
home
from
work
,
and
otherwise
,
who
hurry
quickly
through
,
wake
the
echo
with
their
voice
,
and
soon
darken
the
small
door
in
the
distance
,
as
they
pass
into
the
street
beyond
;
some
,
in
busy
conference
together
on
political
or

matter
,
pace
slowly
up
and
down
with
eye
that
seek
the
ground
,
and
seem
,
by
their

,
to
listen

from
head
to

.
 
<EOS>
here
,
a
dozen
squabble
urchin
make
a
very
Babel
in
the
air
;
there
,
a
solitary
man
,
half

,
half

,
pace

and
down
with
hungry

in

look
and

;
at

pass
an
errand
-
lad
,
swinge
his

round
and
round
,
and
with
his
shrill

rive
the
very
timber
of
the
roof
;
while
a
more
observant

,
half
-
way
through
,
pocket
his

,
and
eye
the
distant
beadle
as
he
come

.
 
<EOS>
It
be
that
time
of
evening
<EOS>
when
,
if
you
shut
your
eye
and
open

again
,
the
darkness
of
an
hour
appear
to
have

.
 
<EOS>
the
smooth
-
wear

,
dusty
with

,
still
call
upon

to
reiterate

the

of

unceasingly
,
save

resound

like

of

,
and
drown

other

in

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
,
glance
only
at
such
of
these
group
as
he
pass
nearest
to
,
and
<EOS>
then
in

betoken
that
his

be
elsewhere
,
have

Hall
,
when

person
before

catch

.
 
<EOS>
one
of
these
,
a

,

,

on
<EOS>
;
the
other
,

,

,

---
at

himself
---

<EOS>

,
who
lift

,
as
if

of

,

of

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
he
retort
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
"
look
you
here
,
my
lord
.
 
<EOS>
do
you
know
this
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lord
George
reply
by
lay

his

,
and
view

.
  
<EOS>
"
this

,
"
say

,
eye

,
"
who
in

,

have
be

,

,

:
<EOS>
this

,

have

,

;

,

,

have

,

:

,

<EOS>

"

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
here

to

no
-

<EOS>
for

.
 
<EOS>
for

!
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

be

,

.
  
<EOS>

Gordon

on

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
John

(

John

;

's

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
44
    
<EOS>
when
the

separate
,
and
,
divide
into

cluster
,
draw

,
there
still

upon

,
one
man
.
 
<EOS>
this
man
be
Gashford
,
who
,
bruise
by

late

,
and
hurt

a
much

by

have

,
and

which

have
be

,

and
down
,

.
  
<EOS>
It
be
not
the
secretary
's
nature
to
waste

in

.
<EOS>
while
he
vent
the
froth
of
his

in
those

,
he
keep
a

on
two
man
,
who
,
have
disappear
with
the
rest
when
the

be
spread
,
have
since

,
and
be
now

in

,
at
no

,
as

walk

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
He
make
no

,
but
wait

on
the

of

street
,
until

be
tired
of
stroll
backwards
and

and

.
 
<EOS>
then
he
follow
,
but
at
some
distance
:
keep
them
in
view
,
without
appear
to
have
that
object
,
or
be
see
by

.
  
<EOS>
They
go
up
Parliament
Street
,
past
Saint
Martin
's
church
,
and
away
by
Saint
Giles
's
to
Tottenham
Court
Road
,
at
the
back
of
which
,
upon

western
side
,
be
then
a
place
call
the
Green
Lanes
.
 
<EOS>
this
be
a
retired
spot
,
not
of
the
choice
kind
,
lead
into
the
field
.
 
<EOS>
great
heap
of
ashe
;
stagnant
pool
,
overgrow
with
rank
grass
and
duckweed
;
break
turnstile
;
and
the
upright
post
of
paling
long
since
carry
off
for
firewood
,
which
menace
all
heedless
walker
with
their
jagged
and
rusty
nail
;
be
the
lead
feature
of
the
landscape
:
while
here
and
there
a
donkey
,
or
a
ragged
horse
,
tether
to
a
stake
,
and
crop
off
a
wretched
meal
from
the
coarse
stunt
turf
,
be
quite
in
keeping
with
the
scene
,
and
would
have
suggest
(
if
the
house
have
not
do
so
,
sufficiently
,
of
themselves
)
<EOS>
how
very
poor
the
people
be
who
live
in
the
crazy
hut
adjacent
,
and
how
foolhardy
it
may
prove
for
one
who
carry
money
,
or
wear
decent
clothe
,
to
walk
that
way
alone
,
unless
by
daylight
.
  
<EOS>
poverty
have
its
whim
and
show
of
taste
,
as
wealth
have
.
 
<EOS>
some
of
these
cabin
be
turrete
,
some
have
false
window
paint
on
their
rotten
wall
;
one
have
a
mimic
clock
,
upon
a
crazy
tower
of
four
foot
high
,
which
screen
the
chimney
;
each
in
its
little
patch
of
ground
have
a
rude

or
arbour
.
 
<EOS>
the
population
deal
in
bone
,
in
rag
,
in
break
glass
,
in
old
wheel
,
in
bird
,
and
dog
.
<EOS>
these
,
in
their
several
way
of
stowage
,
fill
the
garden
;
and
shed
a
perfume
,
not
of
the
most
delicious
nature
,
in
the
air
,
fill
it
besides
with
yelps
,
and

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
into
this
retreat
,
the
secretary
follow
the
two
man
whom
he
have
hold
in
sight
;
and
here
he
see

,
in
one
of

mean

,
which
be
but

room
,
and
that
of

.
<EOS>
He
wait
without
,
until
the

of
their

,
join
in
a

,
assure
him
they
be
make

;
and
then
approach

,
by
mean
of
a

which
cross
the
ditch
in
front
,
knock

.
  
<EOS>
"
Muster
Gashfordl
"
say
the
man
who
open

,
take
his

<EOS>
Chapter
45
    
<EOS>
while
the
bad
passion
of
the
bad
man
be
thus
work
in
the
dark
,
and
the
mantle
of
religion
,
assume
to

ugliest

,
threaten
to

of
all
that
be
good

in

,
a

occur
which
once

alter

position
of
two
person
from
whom
this

have
long
be
separate
,
and
to
whom
it
must
now
return
.
  
<EOS>
in
a
small
english
country
town
,
the
inhabitant
of
which
support
themselves
by
the
labour
of
their
hand
in
plait
and
prepare
straw
for
those
who
make
bonnet
and
other
article
of
dress
and
ornament
from
that
material
,
---
conceal
under
an
assumed
name
,
and
live
in
a
quiet
poverty
which
know
no
change
,
no
pleasure
,
and
few
care
but
that
of
struggle
on
from
day
to
day
in
one
great
toil
for
bread
,
---
dwelt
Barnaby
and
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Their
poor
cottage
have
know
no
stranger
's
foot
since
they
seek
the
shelter
of
its
roof
five
year
before
;
nor
have
they
in
all
that

hold
any

or

with
the
old
world
from
which
they
have
flee
.
 
<EOS>
to
labour
in
peace
,
and
devote
her

and
her

to
her
poor
son
,
be

widow

.
 
<EOS>
if

be
say
at
any
time
to
be
the

one
on
whom
a
secret

prey
,
she

now
.
 
<EOS>
tranquillity
,

,
and
her

of
him
who
need

so

,
form
the
small

of
her
quiet

;
and
while
that
remain
unbroken
,
she
be
content
.
  
<EOS>
for
Barnaby
himself
,
the
time
which
have
fly
by
,
have
pass
him
like
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
the
daily
sun
of
year
have
shed
no

of
reason
on
his
mind
;
no

have
break
on
his
long
,

night
.
<EOS>
He
would
sit
sometimes
---
often

on

or

,

(
for
he
have

art
his
mother
ply
)
,
and

,
God

,

tale
she
would

,
as
a

to

.
 
<EOS>
He
have
no

of
these
little

;
the
tale
of
yesterday
be
new
to
him
upon
the
morrow
;
but
he
like
them
at
the
moment
;
and
when
the
humour
hold
him
,
would
remain
patiently
within
door
,
hear
her
story
like
a
little
child
,
and
work
cheerfully
from
sunrise
until
it
be
too
dark
to
see
.
  
<EOS>
at
other
time
,
---
and
then
their
scanty
earning
be
barely

to

with

,
though
of

,
---
 
he

wander

from

until
the

.
 
<EOS>
few
in
that
place
,
even
of

child
,
could

,
and

have

.
 
<EOS>
indeed

not
many
who
could
have
keep

ramble
,
<EOS>
have

.
 
<EOS>
but

dog

,
who
serve

.
<EOS>
with

,

,

long

that

;
and
though
,
on

,

,
and
almost

,

be

,

.
 
<EOS>
on

,
Grip
,
in

,
be

,
and
when

in

,
no
dog
bark

than
the
raven
.
  
<EOS>
Their

on
these

be
simple
enough
.
 
<EOS>
a

and

,
with
water

,

.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
's
enjoyment
be
,
to
walk
,
and

,
and
leap
,
till

be

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
there
be
wild
-

to

---
the

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

bird

;

;

;

:
<EOS>
million

<EOS>
in

---
deep

---
 
like

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

---

---

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
within

;
and

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
48

<EOS>
he
know
!
"
 
<EOS>
and
so

with

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
say

,
"
that
be
a
brave

he
talk
of
.
 
<EOS>
come
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
not
to
join

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
yes
,
yes
,
"
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
why
not
?
 
<EOS>
come
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do

"

,
"
what

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Dear

,
for

---
<EOS>
"
  
"

!
"
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
well
!
<EOS>
It
be
for

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

the

say
,
about

.
 
<EOS>
here
be
a

!
 
<EOS>
come
!
 
<EOS>
or

---
<EOS>
yes
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
be
stoop

,

pass

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
young

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
who
be
that
?
"
<EOS>
cry

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
do
you
wear
this

?
"
return
the

,
hold
out
a
blue

.
  
<EOS>
"
in
Heaven
's
name
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
not
give
it
him
!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

man
within

,

.
"
<EOS>

to

;
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
,

,

"
<EOS>
yes
!
<EOS>
yes
,

,
I
do
,
"
as

have
cry
a

.
 
<EOS>
the
man
throw

a

,

,
"
make
haste
to
St
George
's
Fields
,
"

to

;
and

.
  
<EOS>
with

that

,

be
adjust

as

best

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
observe

,
and

how
Barnaby
be

,

,

for
an

,
turn

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

,

be

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
why
have
you
not

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
be
go
,

,
"
reply

,
finish

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
say
"

,
"

,

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

Lord

Gordon

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
,
Gashford
,
"

,
as

"
it

,

.
<EOS>
put

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

have
know

"

,
"
it

.
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

<EOS>
We
be

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
amen
!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

of

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
this
be

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
in

's

,

,

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
dear

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

be

,

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
oh

!
 
<EOS>
He
be

,

"
  
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.

"

"
of
be

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
which

---
<EOS>

,

!
"

"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

,
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

---

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
to

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
kiss

be

,
for
their

be

make

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
,
poor
woman
,
follow

---
with
how
much

it
would

hard
to

.
  
<EOS>
They
pass
quickly
through
the
Bridge
Road
,
where
the
shop
be
all

up
(
for

of

and

of

have

for

good
and

)
,
and
where
,
in
the
upper
story
,
all
the
inhabitant
be

,
look
down
into
the
street
below
,
with
face
variously

of

,
of

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
some
of
these
applaud
,
and
some
hissed
;
but
regardless
of
these
interruption
---
for
the
noise
of
a
vast
congregation
of
people
at
a
little

,
sound
in
his

like

the

---
Lord
George
Gordon
quicken
his
pace
,
and
presently
arrive
before
St
George
's
field
.
  
<EOS>
They
be
really
field
at
that
time
,
and
of
considerable
extent
.
<EOS>
here
an
immense
multitude
be
collect
,
bear
flag
of
various
kind
and
size
,
but
all
of
the
same
colour
---
blue
,
like
the
cockade
---
some
section
march
to
and
fro
in
military
array
,
and
other
draw
up
in
circle
,
square
,
and
line
.
 
<EOS>
a
large
portion
,
both
of
the
body
which
parade
the
ground
,
and
of
those
which
remain
stationary
,
be
occupy
in
singe
hymn
or
psalm
.
<EOS>
with
whomsoever
this
originate
,
it
be
well
do
;
for
the
sound
of
so
many
thousand
voice
in
the
air
must
have
stir
the
heart
of
any
man
within
him
,
and
could
not
fail
to
have
a
wonderful
effect
upon
enthusiast
,
however
mistaken
.
  
<EOS>
scout
have
be
post
in
advance
of
the
great
body
,
to
give
notice
of
their
leader
's
come
.
 
<EOS>
these
fall
back
,
the
word
be
quickly
pass
through
the
whole
host
,
and
for
a
short
interval
there
ensue
a
profound
and
deathlike
silence
,
during
which
the
mass
be
so
still
and
quiet
,
that
the
fluttering
of
a
banner
catch
the
eye
,
and
become
a
circumstance
of
note
.
 
<EOS>
then
they
burst
into
a
tremendous
shout
,
into
another
,
and
another
;
and
the
air
seem
rent
and
shake
,
as
if
by
the
discharge
of
cannon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gashford
!
"
cry
Lord
George
,
press
his
secretary
's
arm
tight
within
his
own
,
and
speak
with
as
much
emotion
in
his
voice
,
as
in
his
altered
face
,
<EOS>
"
I
arn
call
indeed
,
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
and
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
be
the
leader
of
a
host
.
 
<EOS>
if
they
summon
me
at
this
moment
with
one
voice
to
lead
them
on
to
death
,
I
would
do
it
---
<EOS>
yes
,
and
fall
first
myself
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
be
a
proud
sight
,
"
say
the
secretary
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
be
a
noble
day
for
England
,
and
for
the
great
cause
throughout
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
such
homage
,
my
lord
,
as
I
,
an
humble
but
devoted
man
,
can
render
---
"
  
"
what
be
you
do
?
"
<EOS>
cry
his
master
,
catch
him
by
both
hand
;
for
he
have
make
a
show
of
kneel
at
his
foot
.
 
<EOS>
"
do
not
unfit
me
,
dear
Gashford
,
for
the
solemn
duty
of
this
glorious
day
---
"
the
tear
stand
in
the
eye
of
the
poor
gentleman
as
he
say
the
word
.
<EOS>
---
"
let
us
go
among
them
;
we
have
to
find
a
place
in
some
division
for
this
new
recruit
---
give
me
your
hand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Gashford
slide
his
cold
insidious
palm
into
his
master
's
grasp
,
and
so
,
hand
in
hand
,
and
follow
still
by
Barnaby
and
by
his
mother
too
,
they
mingle
with
the
concourse
.
  
<EOS>
They
have
by
this
time
take
to
their
singing
again
,
and
as
their
leader
pass
between
their
rank
,
they
raise
their
voice
to
their
utmost
.
 
<EOS>
many
of
those
who
be
band
together
to
support
the
religion
of
their
country
,
even
unto
death
,
have
never
hear
a
hymn
or
psalm
in
all
their
life
.
 
<EOS>
but
these
fellow
have
for
the
most
part
strong
lung
,
and
be
naturally
fond
of
singe
,
chant
any
ribaldry
or
nonsense
that
occur
to
them
,
feel
pretty
certain
that
it
would
not
be
detect
in
the
general
chorus
,
and
not
care
much
if
it
be
.
 
<EOS>
many
of
these
voluntary
be
sing
under
the
very
nose
of
Lord
George
Gordon
,
who
,
quite
unconscious
of
their
burden
,
pass
on
with
his
usual
stiff
and
solemn
deportment
,
very
much
edify
and
delight
by
the
pious
conduct
of
his
follower
.
  
<EOS>
so
they
go
on
and
on
,
up
this
line
,
down
that
<EOS>
,
round
the
exterior
of
this
circle
,
and
on
every
side
of
that
hollow
square
;
and
still
there
be
line
,
and
square
,
and
circle
out
of
number
to
review
.
<EOS>
the
day
be
now

hot
,
and
the

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
still

,

on

the
task
devolve
,
that
it
be
time
to
take
possession
of
the
lobby
of
both
Houses
,
and
of
the
various
avenue
of
approach
,
and
of
the
gallery
stair
.
 
<EOS>
to
the
last
-
name
place
,
Hugh
and
Dennis
,
still
with
their
pupil
between
them
,
rush
straightway
;
Barnaby
have
give
his
flag
into
the
hand
of
one
of
their
own
party
,
who
keep
them
at
the
outer
door
.
 
<EOS>
Their
follower
press
on
behind
,
they
be
bear
as
on
a
great
wave
to
the
very
door
of
the
gallery
,
whence
it
be
impossible
to
retreat
,
even
if
they
have
be
so
inclined
,
by
reason
of
the
throng
which
choke
up
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
a
familiar
expression
in
describe
a
great
crowd
,
that
a
person
may
have
walk
upon
the
people
's
head
.
 
<EOS>
in
this
case
it
be
actually
do
;
for
a
boy
who
have
by
some
mean
get
among
the
concourse
,
and
be
in
imminent
danger
of
suffocation
,
climb
to
the
shoulder
of
a
man
beside
him
and
walk
upon
the
people
's
hat
and
head
into
the
open
street
;
traverse
in
his
passage
the
whole
length
of
two
staircase
and
a
long
gallery
.
 
<EOS>
nor
be
the
swarm
without
less
dense
;
for
a
basket
which
have
be
toss
into
the
crowd
,
be
jerk
from
head
to
head
,
and
shoulder
to
shoulder
,
and
go
spin
and
whirl
on
above
them
,
until
it
be
lose
to
view
,
without
ever
once
fall
in
among
them
or
come
near
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
through
this
vast
throng
,
sprinkle
doubtless
here
and
there
with
honest
zealot
,
but
compose
for
the
most
part
of
the
very
scum
and
refuse
of
London
,
whose
growth
be
foster
by
bad
criminal
law
,
bad
prison
regulation
,
and
the
bad
conceivable
police
,
such
of
the
member
of
both
Houses
of
Parliament
as
have
not
take
the
precaution
to
be
already
at
their
post
,
be
compel
to
fight
and
force
their
way
.
 
<EOS>
Their
carriage
be
stop
and
break
;
the
wheel
wrench
off
;
the
glass
shiver
to
atom
;
the
panel
beat
in
;
driver
,
footman
,
and
master
,
pull
from
their
seat
and
roll
in
the
mud
.
 
<EOS>
Lords
,
commoner
,
and
reverend
bishop
,
with
little
distinction
of
person
or
party
,
be
kick
and
pinch
and
hustle
;
pass
from
hand
to
hand
through
various
stage
of
ill
-
usage
;
and
send
to
their
fellow
-
senator
at
last
with
their
clothe
hang
in
riband
about
them
,
their
bagwigs
tear
off
,
themselves
speechless
and
breathless
,
and
their
person
cover
with
the
powder
which
have
be
cuff
and
beat
out
of
their
hair
.
<EOS>
one
lord
be
so
long
in
the
hand
of
the
populace
,
that
the
Peers
as
a
body
resolve
to
sally
forth
and
rescue

,
and
be
in
the
act
of
do
so
,
when
he
happily
appear
among
them
cover
with
dirt
and
bruise
,
and
hardly
to
be
recognise
by
those
who
know
him
best
.
 
<EOS>
the
noise
and
uproar
be
on
the
increase
every
moment
.
 
<EOS>
the
air
be
fill
with
execration
,
hoot
,
and
howling
.
 
<EOS>
the
mob
rage
and
roar
,
like
a
mad
monster
as
it
be
,
unceasingly
,
and
each
new
outrage
serve
to
swell
its
fury
.
  
<EOS>
within
door
,
matter
be
even
yet
more
threatening
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
George
---
 
precede
by
a
man
who
carry
the
immense
petition
on
a
porter
's

through
the
lobby
to
the

of

,

be

by
two

who
roll

up
to
the
table
ready

---
have
take
his
seat
at
an

,
before
the
Speaker
go
to

.
 
<EOS>
His

pour
in
at
the
same

,
the
lobby
and
all
the

be

fill
,

we
have
see
.
 
<EOS>
thus
the
member
be
not
only
attack
in

through

,
but
be
set
upon
within
the

of

;
while

,

,
be

,

:
far

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
so
sure
as
any

,
just

,
with
dress

and

,
come

through

in

,
it
yell
and

in

;
and
when
the

of

,

and

open
by

for

,
give

of
the

,
they
grow
more
wild
and

,
like
beast
at
the
sight
of
prey
,
and
make
a
rush
against
the
portal
which
strain
its
lock
and
bolt
in
their
staple
,
and

beam
.
  
<EOS>
the
stranger
'
gallery
,
which
be
immediately
above

of

House
,
have
be
order
to
be
close

,

;
save
that
now
<EOS>
and

Lord
George
take

,
for

of
come

which

,

what
have
pass

.
 
<EOS>
It
be

that
Barnaby
,
Hugh
,
and

be
post
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
two
flight
,
short
,
steep
,
and

,
run

to

,

door
communicate

which

.
<EOS>
between

be
a
kind
of
well
,
or
unglazed

,
for
the

of
light
and

into

,

may

some

foot

.
  
<EOS>
upon

staircase
---
not

Lord
George
appear
from

,

---
Gashford
stand

on

,
and

rest

,

.
 
<EOS>
whenever

vary

in

---
so

as
by

---
the

be
certain

,

,

;
from

no

,

act

,
be

.
  
<EOS>
"
order
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Hugh
,
in
a
voice
which
make
itself
hear
even
above
the

and

,
as

George
appear

.
 
<EOS>
"
News
!
 
<EOS>
news
from
my
lord
!
"
  
<EOS>
the

continue
,
notwithstanding
his

,
until
Gashford
look

.
 
<EOS>
there
be

immediately
---
even

in
the

without
,
and
on

other

,
who
could

,
but

,

,

be

.
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
"
say
Lord
George
,
who
be
very
pale
and
agitated
,
we
must
be
firm
.
 
<EOS>
They
talk
of
delay
,
but
we
must
have

.
<EOS>
They
talk
of
take
your
petition
into

next

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
present
appearance
look
bad
for
our

,
but
we
must
succeed
and
will
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
must
succeed
and
will
!
"
echo
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
and
so
among
their
shout
and
cheer
and
other

,
he
bow
to
them
and
retire
,

back

.
 
<EOS>
there
be
another

from
Gashford
,
and
a

directly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
be

,
"
he
say
,
this

,
"
that

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
but

redress

own
grievance
<EOS>
,

meet
again
,
we

put

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
this
speech
be
a

than

,
be
not

receive
.
 
<EOS>
when

and

be
at

,
he
come
back
once
more
,
and
tell

that
the
alarm
have
go
forth
for
many

;
that
when
the
King
hear
of
their
assemble
together
in

,

have

,

;

---
with

as

,

,

---
be

,

,
and
press
past

and
come

,
confront

.
  
<EOS>
the

of
this

quite
take

by

.
 
<EOS>
They
be
not
the
less
disconcert
,
<EOS>
when
one
of
the
gentleman
,
turn

Lord
George
,
speak

---
in

that

may

,

:
  
"

,

,

,

General

of
whom

;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

a

,
you

,
and
I

protect
the

of
this

with

.
 
<EOS>
You
see
,
my
lord
,
that
the
member
of
this

be
all
in
arm
to
-
day
;
you
know
that

entrance
to

be
a

one
;
you
can
not

that
there
be
man
within

who
be

pass
to

,
and
<EOS>
before

must
fall
if

.
 
<EOS>
have
a

what
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
and
my
Lord
George
,
"
say

,

,
"
I

,
from

---
<EOS>
Colonel
Gordon
---
 
your
near
relation
.
 
<EOS>
if

man
among
this

,

strike

,
cross

,
I

that

---
not

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
with

,
they
step

,

;
take

an
arm
of

misguided
nobleman
;

into

,

;
which

directly

and

on

.
  
<EOS>
this
be
so

do
,
and

of

---
who
be

---

,
that

and

.
 
<EOS>
many
try

turn

;
some
of

have
best
go

,

to

;
and

and

be

,
when
Gashford
whisper
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
what
now
!
"
<EOS>
Hugh
roar

,
turn

.
 
<EOS>
"
why
go
back
?
<EOS>
where
can
you
do
better
than
here
,
boy
!
 
<EOS>
one
good

against
these
door
and

below
at
the

,
will
do

.
<EOS>
rush
on
,

!
 
<EOS>
as
to
the
door

,
let
those
stand
back
who
be

.
 
<EOS>
let

who
be

,
try

to
pass

.
 
<EOS>
here

!
 
<EOS>
look
out
down
there
!
"
  
<EOS>
without

of
an

,
he
throw

into

.
 
<EOS>
He
have

when
Barnaby
be
at

.
 
<EOS>
the

's

,

,

;
and

,

,

throw

against

door
pell
-

,
and
besiege

House
in

.
  
<EOS>
at
that

,
when

must
have
bring

with

the

within
,

case
great

of

and

would

,
---

give

,

from

that

have

,

.
 
<EOS>
Fearful
of
sustain

in

in

be
so

wedge

,

.
 
<EOS>

turn

,

go

:
and
<EOS>
so
,

fall
man
and
be

on
in
turn

,
they
and

float

into

,

of

,

,
come

;
clear

so

that

seem

as

.
  
<EOS>
the

to

be
give
,

form

the

;

,

and

,
form

,

.
 
<EOS>

ride

into

between

,

and

of

,

a

.
 
<EOS>
the
Riot
Act
be
read
,
but
not
a
man
stir
.
  
<EOS>
in
the
first
rank
of
the
insurgent
,

and
Hugh
stand
side

.
 
<EOS>
somebody
have
thrust
into
Barnaby
's
hand
when
he
come

into
the
street
,
his
precious
flag
;
which
,
be
now
roll
up
and
tie
round
the
pole
,
look
like
a
giant
quarter
-
staff
as
he
grasp
it
firmly
and
stand
upon
his
guard
.
 
<EOS>
if
ever
man
believe
with
his
whole
heart
and
soul
that
he
be
engage
in
a
just
cause
,
and
that
he
be
bind
to
stand
by
his
leader
to
the
last
,
poor
Barnaby
believe
it
of
himself
and
Lord
George
Gordon
.
  
<EOS>
after
an
ineffectual
attempt
to
make
himself
hear
,
the
magistrate
give
the
word
and
the
Horse
Guards
come
ride
in
among
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
but
,
even
then
,
he
gallop
here
and
there
,
exhort
the
people
to
disperse
;
and
,
although
heavy
stone
be
throw
at
the
man
,
and
some
be
desperately
cut
and
bruise
,
they
have
no
order
but
to
make
prisoner
of
such
of
the
rioter
as
be
the
most
active
,
and
to
drive
the
people
back
with
the
flat
of
their
sabre
.
 
<EOS>
as
the
horse
come
in
among
them
,
the
throng
give
way
at
many
point
,
and
the
Guards
,
follow
up
their
advantage
,
be
rapidly
clear
the
ground
,
when
two
or
three
of
the
foremost
,
who
be
in
a
manner
cut
off
from
the
rest
by
the
people
close
round
them
,
make
straight
towards
Barnaby
and
Hugh
,
who
have
no
doubt
be
point
out
as
the
two
man
who
drop
into
the
lobby
:
lay
about
them
now
with
some
effect
,
and
inflict
on
the
more
turbulent
of
their
opponent
,
a
few
slight
flesh
wound
,
under
the
influence
of
which
a
man
drop
,
here
and
there
,
into
the
arm
of
his
fellow
,
amid
much
groaning
and
confusion
.
  
<EOS>
at
the
sight
of
gash
and
bloody
face
,
see
for
a
moment
in
the
crowd
,
then
hide
by
the
press
around
them
,
Barnaby
turn
pale
and
sick
.
 
<EOS>
but
he
stand
his
ground
,
and
grasp
his
pole
more
firmly
yet
,
keep
his
eye
fix
upon
the
near
soldier
---
nod
his
head
meanwhile
,
as
Hugh
,
with
a
scowling
visage
,
whisper
in
his
ear
.
  
<EOS>
the
soldier
come
spur
on
,
make
his
horse
rear
as
the
people
press
about
him
,
cut
at
the
hand
of
those
who
would
have
grasp
his
rein
and
force
his
charger
back
,
and
wave
to
his
comrade
to
follow
---
and
still
Barnaby
,
without
retreat
an
inch
,
wait
for
his
coming
.
 
<EOS>
some
call
to
him
to
fly
,
and
some
be
in
the
very
act
of
closing
round
him
,
to
prevent
his
be
take
,
when
the
pole
sweep
into
the
air
above
the
people
's
head
,
and
the
man
's
saddle
be
empty
in
an
instant
.
  
<EOS>
then
,
he
and
Hugh
turn
and
flee
,
the
crowd
opening
to
let
them
pass
,
and
close
up
again
so
quickly
that
there
be
no
clue
to
the
course
they
have
take
.
 
<EOS>
pant
for
breath
,
hot
,

,
and
exhaust
with
fatigue
,
they
reach
the
riverside
in
safety
,
and
get
into
a
boat
with
all
despatch
be
soon
out
of
any
immediate
danger
.
  
<EOS>
as
they
glide
down
the
river
,
they
plainly
hear
the
people
cheer
;
and
supposing
they
may
have
force
the
soldier
to
retreat
,
lie
upon
their
oar
for
a
few
minute
,
uncertain
whether
to
return
or
not
.
 
<EOS>
but
the
crowd
pass
along
Westminster
Bridge
,
soon
assure
them
that
the
populace
be
disperse
;
and
Hugh
rightly
guess
from
this
,
that
they
have
cheer
the
magistrate
for
offer
to
dismiss
the
military
on
condition
of
their
immediate
departure
to
their
several
home
,
and
that
he
and
Barnaby
be
well
where
they
be
.
 
<EOS>
He
advise
,
therefore
,
that
they
should
proceed
to
Blackfriars
,
and
,
go
ashore
at
the
bridge
,
make
the
good
of
their
way
to
the
Boot
;
where
there
be
not
only
good
entertainment
and
safe

,
but
where
they
would
certainly
be
join
by
many
of
their
late
companion
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
assenting
<EOS>
,
they
decide
on
this
course
of
action
,
and
pull
for
Blackfriars
accordingly
.
  
<EOS>
They
land
at
a
critical
time
,
and
fortunately
for
themselves
at
the
right
moment
.
 
<EOS>
for
,
come
into
Fleet
Street
,
they
find
it
in
an
unusual

;
and
inquire
the
cause
,
be
tell
that
a
body
of
Horse
Guards
have
just
gallop
past
,
and
that
they
be
escort
some
rioter
whom
they
have
make
prisoner
,
to
Newgate
for

.
<EOS>
not
at
all
ill
-
pleased
to
have
so
narrowly
escape
the
cavalcade
<EOS>
,
they
lose
no

time
in
ask

,
but
hurry
to
the
Boot
with

as
Hugh
consider

prudent
to
make
,
without
appear
singular
or

share
of
public

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
50
    
<EOS>
They
be
among
the
first
to
reach
the
tavern
,
but
they
have
not
be
there
many
minute
,
when
several
group
of
man
who
have
form

the

,

straggle
in
.
 
<EOS>
among
them
be
Simon
Tappertit
and
Mr
Dennis
;
both

,
but
especially

,
greet
Barnaby
with
the

,
and
pay

many

on
the

he
have
show
.
  
<EOS>
"
which
,
"
say
Dennis
,
with
an

,

rest

in

,

,
"
it
do

good
to
think

.
 
<EOS>
there
be
a
opportunity
!
<EOS>
but
it
lead
to
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
for

,
I
do
not

what
would
.
<EOS>
there
be
no
spirit
among
the
people
in
these
here
time
.
 
<EOS>
bring
something
to
eat
and

here
.
 
<EOS>
I
be
disgusted
with
humanity
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
on
what

?
"

Tappertit
,
who
have
be
quench
his
fiery

in
a
half
-
gallon
<EOS>
can
.
 
<EOS>
"
do
not
you
consider
this
a
good

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
give

that

an't
a
ending
,
"
rejoin

hangman
.
<EOS>
"
when
that

go

,
we
may
have
make
London
our
;
but
no
;
---
we
stand
,
and

,
and
look

---
the
justice
(
I
wish

have

in

,
as

would
have
have
,
if
we
would
go

work

)
<EOS>

,
"

lad
,

,

,
"
our

,

,

cur

.
 
<EOS>
ah
,
"

,

,
"
it
make

feller

.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
have
be
bear
a
ox
,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
do

,
"

,
call

;
"
if

horn

at

present

,
with
the

sense
,

,

,
"
mean

,
"
for
his

himself
this

.
"
  
<EOS>
with
which

of

,
Mr
Dennis
seek

in
cold
boil

and

;
but
without

the

of

,
the

be
rather
deepen
than

by

.
  
<EOS>
the
company
who
be
thus
libel
may
have
retaliate
by
strong

,
if

,
but
they
be
dispirit
and

.
 
<EOS>
the
great

them
have
fast
since
morning
;
all
have
suffer
extremely
from
the

;
and
between
the
day
's

,

,

,
many
have
quite
lose

,
and
so
much
of

that

stand
.
 
<EOS>
then

be
uncertain

,

,

,
but

bad
than

.
 
<EOS>
of

who
have
come
to
the
Boot
,
many
drop

;
such

as

,

,

's

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

;
other

theretofore

,

.
 
<EOS>
the
half
-

have
take
,

into
half
-
a
-

;
and

,
be

,

,

,
that

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
even

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
oh
!
you

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
"

,

,

!

<EOS>

.

"
oh

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>

.

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

!

"

,

<EOS>

!
"

<EOS>
Chapter
52
    
<EOS>
a
mob
be
usually
a

of
very
mysterious
existence
,
particularly
in
a
large

.
 
<EOS>
where

or

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
assemble

,

;

,
for
the
ocean
<EOS>
be
not
more
fickle

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
the

.
<EOS>
allow

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

,

"

<EOS>
whether

<EOS>
to

the

begin

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
53
    
<EOS>
the

usher

;

,

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
indeed
,

of
have

,

.
 
<EOS>
many

,

,

;

<EOS>

;

active

other
know
they
must
be
suspect
,
and
that
they
would
be
discharge
if
they
return
;
other
have
be
desperate
from
the
beginning
,
and
comfort
themselves
with
the
homely
proverb
,
that
,
be
hang
at
all
,
they
may
as
well
be
hang
for
a

as
a

.
 
<EOS>
They
all
hope
and
believe
,
in
a
great
or
less
degree
,
that
the
government
they
seem
to
have
paralysed
,
would
,
in
its
terror
,
come
to

them
in
the
end
,
and
suffer

to
make
their
own
condition
.
 
<EOS>
the
least
sanguine
among
them
reason
with

that
,
at
the
bad
,
they
be
too
many
to
be
all
punish
,
and
that
he
have
as
good

escape
as
any

.
 
<EOS>
the
great
mass
never
reason
or
think
at
all
,
but
be
stimulate
by
their
own
headlong
passion
,
by

,
by

,
by
the
love
of

,
and
the

of

.
  
<EOS>
one
other
circumstance
be
worthy
of
remark
;
and
that
is
,
that
from
the
moment
of
their
first
outbreak
at
Westminster
,
every

of
order
or
preconcerte
arrangement
among

.
 
<EOS>
when

divide
into

and
run
to
different

,

be
on

moment
.
 
<EOS>
each

swell
as
it
go
along
,
like
river
as

towards
the

;
new

as

be
want
,

be

,

.
 
<EOS>
each

take

form
from
the

of
the

;
sober

,
go

see

instant
<EOS>
;
mere

<EOS>
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

,
and

,

for

.
 
<EOS>
the

,

<EOS>
Chapter
54

know
,
"
return
Solomon
Daisy
,
"
his
house
be
a
goodish
way
out
of
London
,
and

that
the
rioter
will
not
go
more

,
or

at
the

,
off

.
<EOS>
besides
,
you

,
some

have

send
trinket

suchlike
down

---
at

the

go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
the

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
the
story
go
that
you
see
a

.
 
<EOS>
but
nobody
believe

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
well
!
"

,
rise

:
"

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
so

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

into

,
"
with

as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
the

;

,

,

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
John

look

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
when

---

.
  
<EOS>
how

,
matter

;

,

,

have
fade
<EOS>
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

,

,

;

leave
.
 
<EOS>
how

,

!
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Hark
!
 
<EOS>
something

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
It
be
on

,

.
 
<EOS>

---
the

,

of

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
yes
.
 
<EOS>
here

,

,

:

,

<EOS>

,

more

,

,

<EOS>
noise
,

,

,

!
"
<EOS>
cry
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
no
,
brother
?
"
return

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
what
else
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
there
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
that

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
but
,

truss

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

<EOS>
Hugh
,
infer

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
a
witness
's

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
a

follow
,

.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
linger

,

,

<EOS>
light

,

,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
55
    
John
Willet
,
leave
alone
in
his
dismantle

,
continue
to
sit
stare

;
awake

,

,

in

.
 
<EOS>
He
look
round
upon
the
room
which
have
be
for
year
,
and
be
within
an
hour
ago
,
the
pride
of
his
heart
;
and
not
a

of

.
 
<EOS>
the
night
,
without
,
look
black
and

through
the
dreary

the

;
the

,

,

;

peer

in

,
like

;
the

may
have
be

,
it
be

.
 
<EOS>
current
of
air
rush
in
,
as
the
old
door
jar
and
creak
upon
their

;
the

flicker

gutter
down
,
and
make
long

;
the
cheery
deep
-
red
curtain
flap
and

in

;
even

,

,
seem

have

,

could

.
 
<EOS>
John
see
this

,

yet
see

.
 
<EOS>
He
be
perfectly

sit

,
stare

,

have
be

.
 
<EOS>
so

he
be

concern
,
old

lie

,

.
  
<EOS>
save

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
have

<EOS>
a

.
  
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
It
be
the
Bell
.
 
<EOS>
if
the

shape
the

have

have

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
with

that

,

,

most

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

;
then

,

:
still
,
still
,
the
Bell
toll

and
seem

---
loud

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

grow

,
the

of

deeper
;

body
fall
,

;

;

---
 
rise

,
to

---
a

---

after

---
 
speak

---
the
Bell
---
the
Bell
!
  
<EOS>
what
hunt
of
spectre
could
surpass
that
dread
pursuit
and

!
<EOS>
have

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
the
one
pursue

be

:

sound

,

;
shake

long

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

catch

,

,

be

:

,

;

be

;

be

;

be

:

---
the
Bell
,
the
Bell
!
  
<EOS>
It
cease
;
but

.
 
<EOS>
the

be

.
 
<EOS>
no

of

have

like

which
sound

,

warn

that

.
 
<EOS>
who
could

that

,
and
not

it
say
!
 
<EOS>
there

in

---

,

---
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
Its

summon

.
 
<EOS>
what
face
be

,

,

,

,

,

stag
'

when

:
shrink

<EOS>
---

<EOS>
---

!
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

:

,

,

---

,

,

,
the

could

!
  
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

form

,

.
 
<EOS>
rumour
of
their
approach
<EOS>
have
go

,

,

,

:

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,
and
confer

the
course

.
  
<EOS>
very

be

,
when
all
be

upon

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

be
give

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

,

;

,

,
to

.
  
<EOS>
no

,

,
---

,

)

,

,

,
---
 
struggle
into

,

.
 
<EOS>
They
have
not
at

more

light

;

,

.
<EOS>

they

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
bare

,

---
chamber
,

<EOS>
Chapter
56
    
<EOS>
the

crony
,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
It
be

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
arrive

,
they
find
that
almost
every
house
have
chalk
upon
its
door
in
large
character
"
no
Popery
,
"
that
the
shop
be
shut
,
and
that
alarm
and
anxiety
be
depict
in
every
face
they
pass
.
  
<EOS>
note
these
thing
with
a
degree
of
apprehension
which
neither
of
the
three
care
to
impart
,
in
its
full
extent
,
to
his
companion
,
they
come
to
a
turnpike
-
gate
,
which
be
shut
.
 
<EOS>
They
be
pass
through
the
turnstile
on
the
path
,
when
a
horseman
ride
up
from
London
at
a
hard

,
and
call
to
the
toll
-
keeper
in
a

of
great

,
to
open
quickly
in
the
name
of
God
.
  
<EOS>
the

be
so

and

,
that
the

,
with
a

in

,
come

out
---
toll
-
keeper
though

be
---
 
and
be
about

,
when
happen

,
he

,
"
<EOS>
Good
Heaven
,
what
be
that
!
 
<EOS>
another
fire
!
"
  
<EOS>
at

,
the
three
turn

,

see

---
 
straight

whence

---
a

,
cast

upon

cloud
,
which
glimmer
as

be
behind

,
and
show

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

misgive

,
"

,
"
or
<EOS>
I

come
.
 
<EOS>
do

,
my

.
<EOS>
open

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"

"

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

pass
,

.
 
<EOS>
You

be
murder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
so
be
it
!
"
<EOS>

,

fire
,

not
at

.
  
<EOS>
"
but

---
sir
,
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
here
,

,
"

"

;

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

!
"

<EOS>
"

---
worthy

---
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
this

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
,

?
---
N
<EOS>
-

<EOS>
no
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
up

---
behind

---

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
me

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

be

<EOS>

well
<EOS>

,

---

,

---

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
the

be

,

---

---
far

---
by

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

could

.
  
<EOS>
"
down
---

---

,
"

,

Daisy

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Willet
---
 
Willet
---

---
Willet
!
"
  
<EOS>
cry

,

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
the

bind

;
the

,

,

;
---
nobody

.
  
<EOS>
He
be

,
accustom

,

;
but

what

---

---

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Johnny
,
Johnny
,
"

---

,

"

,

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
the

Warren
too
,
<EOS>
Johnny

<EOS>

---

's

,

.
  
<EOS>

.

,

,

"

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

,

,

,

a

,
"

"
Willet
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
Solomon

,

,

"

!
"
  
"
<EOS>

call

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>

,

,

;

,

,

,

,
which
that

's

have
shine

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

stare

,
listen
,

down

to

that
he
be

,

,

,

,

,

from

have
so

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
tie
his
horse
to
the
trunk
of
a
tree
,
and
grasp
his
companion
's
arm
,
steal

along
the

,
and
into
what
have
be
the

of

.
 
<EOS>
He
stop
for
an

to

upon
its

,
and

that
shine
through

upon

ashe
.
 
<EOS>
Solomon
glance

in

face
,
but
his

be

press
together
,
a

sit
upon

,
and

,

,
or

indicate

,

.
  
<EOS>
He
draw
his
sword
;
feel

in

,
as
though

carry
other
arm
about

;
then
grasp
Solomon
by

again
,

with

all
round

.
 
<EOS>
He
look
into
every
doorway
and
gap
in
the
wall
;
retrace

step
at
every
rustling
of
the
air
among
the
leave
;
and
search
in
every
shadow
nook
with
outstretched
hand
.
 
<EOS>
thus
they
make
the
circuit
of
the
building
:
but
they
return
to
the
spot
from
which
they
have
set
out
,
without
encounter
any

,
or
find
the
least

of
any
conceal

.
  
<EOS>
after
a
short
pause
,
Mr
Haredale
shout
twice
or
thrice
.
 
<EOS>
then
cry
aloud
,
"
be
there
any
one
in
hiding
here
,
who
know
my
voice
!
<EOS>
there
be
nothing
to
fear
now
.
 
<EOS>
if
any

my

be
near
,
I

to
answer
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
call

all
by
name
;
his

be
echo
in
many

;
then
all
be

as

.
  
<EOS>
They
be
stand
near
the
foot
of
the

,
where

hang
.
 
<EOS>
the
fire
have
rage
there
,
and
the

have
be
saw
,
and
hewn
,
and
beat

,
besides
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
open
to
the

;
but

still

,
wind

from
a

.
 
<EOS>
fragment
of
the
jagged

step
offer

here

,
and

be

,
behind
protrude
angle

;
for
by

have
rise
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
as

,

,
and

,
some

in
this

.
 
<EOS>
startle

,
Solomon

,

he
have

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

's

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
terrify

and

<EOS>

;
and

<EOS>
again

slip

---
very

again

,

<EOS>
and

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
what

;

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Solomon
turn

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
His

,
and

.
  
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
again

;
some

<EOS>
He
keep

.
 
<EOS>
the

be

,

.
 
<EOS>
now

---
and
now

---
and

---
   
<EOS>
the

"
the

<EOS>
the

!
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

for

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

Chapter
57
    
Barnaby
,
arm
as
we
have
see
,
continue
to
pace
up
and
down
before
the
stable
-
door
;
glad

alone

,

.
 
<EOS>

have
be

.
<EOS>

;

,
and
none

.
  
<EOS>
have

her
,
whose

he
be
,
and
whom

have

?
 
<EOS>
oh
,

.
 
<EOS>

be

.
 
<EOS>

;

for

.
 
<EOS>

give

!
 
<EOS>
ah
!
<EOS>

tell

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

his

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He
have
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

!

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

.
 
<EOS>

foot

:

,

---

,

.
 
<EOS>

---

!
 
<EOS>
down
<EOS>
,
master
,

(

)
---
<EOS>

---

.
  
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Grip
,

,

's

's

.
<EOS>
the

have

fill

,

.
 
<EOS>
golden

,

,
candlestick
,
coin
guinea
---
all
the
rich
be
reveal
.
  
<EOS>
They
bring
spade
and
a

;
dug

that
be
hide
there
;
and
carry
away
more

could

.
 
<EOS>
They
handcuff
him
and

,

,

he

.
 
<EOS>
nobody

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

man
he
have

,
be

in
the

.
 
<EOS>
finally
,
he
be

,

.
  
<EOS>
this
be
soon
complete
.
 
<EOS>
the

form

;

be

,
with

;
and
order

in
,
where
a

be
leave
.
 
<EOS>
the
other
close
up
all

,
and
so

move

,
with
the
prisoner
in

.
  
<EOS>
when

come
into

,
he
feel

be
a
sight
;
and
look

as

,
could

people

to

a

,

.
 
<EOS>
sometimes

meet

,

,

;
but

be

,
be

.
 
<EOS>
the

of

seem

;
and
the

come

and
hot

,

.
  
<EOS>
Tramp
,
tramp
.
 
<EOS>
Tramp
,
tramp
.
 
<EOS>
head
erect
,
shoulder
square
,
every
man
step
in
exact

---
all
so
orderly
and
regular
---
<EOS>
nobody

---
nobody

,
---
he
could

be

.
 
<EOS>
but

,

,
not

,

,

:
<EOS>
the

:

,
now

,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
58
    
<EOS>
They
be
not
long
in
reach
the
barrack
,
for
the
officer
who
command
the
party
<EOS>
be
desirous
to
avoid

by

in
the

,
and
be

;
know

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
this

not

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
arrive

,
poor
Barnaby
be

into

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
the

,

.

"

<EOS>

bird
,
"
say
the
serjeant
testily
;
"
that
be
English
,
an't
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
what
you
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
go
to
the
guard
-
house
,
and
see
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
find
a
bird
there
<EOS>
,
that
be
get
their

as

any
of

,

bawl
"
no

,
"
like
a

---
or

,
as
he

be
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
not

.
 
<EOS>
the

's

London
somewhere
.
 
<EOS>
Damme
if
I
would
not
twist
his

round
,
on
the
chance
,
if
I
have

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
the

have
take

,
as

go
and
see
this

,
when
he
be
arrest

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"
he

,

---
"
my

,

.
 
<EOS>
ha

!
 
<EOS>
do

,
he

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

,

---
very

.
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

no

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

judge
from

to
be

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
but

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

and

,
you

change

---
ay
,

---

!
<EOS>
kill

---

.
 
<EOS>

,

!

<EOS>
have

,

<EOS>

---

"
shed

have

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

be

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
no

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
good

,

,
<EOS>

!
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
not

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

,

,

;

,

;

,
be

.
 
<EOS>

Hugh
!
 
<EOS>
there

among

.
 
<EOS>
be

a

?
 
<EOS>
be

no

!
  
<EOS>
as

nearer

,

grow

;
stone

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
one

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>

,

,

,

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

;

,

,

's

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
59
    
<EOS>
It
be

,

,

,

,

,

have

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

,

;

these

,
be

,

,
where

,

,

<EOS>

:
guide

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>
They

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

be

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
well
!
"

,

"

?
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
---

?
"
  
<EOS>

;

-

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
have

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
another

,

.
 
<EOS>
reserve

to

with
<EOS>
,

:
  
"

,

?
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
which

---

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
be
,

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
do
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

out
!
<EOS>
quick
!
 
<EOS>
show

here
,
