!
 
<EOS>
let

sup
in

,
my

!
 
<EOS>
ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
<EOS>
enter

,
for

have

,

,

,

,

,

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,

;

,
have

,
fall

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

to

every

,

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
seem
to
agree

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
keep

,

"

<EOS>
He
happen
by
great
good
luck
to
have
roar
and
shout
himself
into
silence
by
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
They
be
proceed
onward
without
noise
,
when
a
scout
who
have
be
creep
about
the
ditch
all
night
,
to
warn
any
straggler
from
encroach
further
on
what
be
now
such
dangerous
ground
,
peep
cautiously
from
his
hiding
-
place
,
and
call
to
them
to
stop
.
  
<EOS>
"
stop
!
<EOS>
and
why
?
<EOS>
"
say
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
because
(
the
scout
reply
)
<EOS>
the
house
be
fill
with
constable
and
soldier
;
have
be
surprise
that
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
the
inmate
have
flee
or
be
take
into
custody
,
he
could
not
say
which
.
 
<EOS>
He
have
prevent
a
great
many
people
from
approach
nearer
,
and
he
believe
they
have
go
to
the
market
and
such
place
to
pass
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
have
see
the
distant
fire
,
but
they
be
all
out
now
.
<EOS>
He
have
hear
the
people
who
pass
and
repasse
,
speak
of
them
too
,
and
could
report
that
the
prevail
opinion
be
one
of
apprehension
and
dismay
.
 
<EOS>
He
have
not
hear
a
word
of
Barnaby
---
 
<EOS>
do
not
even
know
his
name
---
but
it
have
be
say
in
his
hearing
that
some
man
have
be
take
and
carry
off
to
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
whether
this
be
true
or
false
,
he
could
not
affirm
.
  
<EOS>
the
three
take
counsel
together
,
on
hear
this
,
and
debate
what
it
may
be
good
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
,
deem
it
possible
that
Barnaby
be
in
the
hand
of
the
soldier
,
and
at
that
moment
under
detention
at
the
Boot
,
be
for
advance
stealthily
,
and
fire
the
house
;
but
his
companion
,
who
object
to
such
rash
measure
unless
they
have
a

at

,
represent
that
if
Barnaby
be
take
he
have
assuredly
be
remove
to
a
strong
prison
;
they
would
never
have
dream
of
keep
him
all
night
in
a
place
so
weak
and
open
to
attack
.
 
<EOS>
yield
to
this
reasoning
,
and
to
their

,
Hugh
consent
to
turn
back
and
to
repair
to
Fleet
Market
;
for
which
place
,
it
seem
,
a
few
of
their
bold
associate
have
shape
their
course
,
on
receive
the
same
intelligence
.
  
<EOS>
feel
their
strength
recruit
and
their
spirit
rouse
,
now
that
there
be
a
new
necessity
for
action
,
they
hurry
away
,
quite
forgetful
of
the
fatigue
under
which
they
have
be
sink
but
a
few
minute
before
;
and
soon
arrive
at
their
new
place
of
destination
.
  
<EOS>
Fleet
Market
,
at
that
time
,
be
a
long
irregular
row
of
wooden
shed
and
penthouse
,
occupy
the
centre
of
what
be
now
call
Farringdon
Street
.
 
<EOS>
They
be
jumble
together
in
a
most
unsightly
fashion
,
in
the
middle
of
the
road
;
to
the
great
obstruction
of
the
thoroughfare
and
the
annoyance
of
passenger
,
who
be
fain
to
make
their

,
as
they
best
could
,
among
cart
,

,
barrow
,

,

,

,
and

,
and
to

with

,

,

,
and
a
motley
crowd
of
buyer
,
seller
,
pick
-
pocket
,

,
and
idler
.
 
<EOS>
the
air
be
perfume
with
the

of
rotten
leave
and
fade

;
the
refuse
of
the
butcher
'
stall
,
and
offal
and

of
a
hundred
kind
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
indispensable
to
most
public
convenience
in
those
day
,
that
they
should
be
public
nuisance
likewise
;
and
Fleet
Market
maintain
the
principle
to
admiration
.
  
<EOS>
to
this
place
,
perhaps
because
its
shed
and

be
a

for

,
or
perhaps

it
afford

of
a

in

,
many
of
the
rioter
have

,
not
only

,
but

night

.
<EOS>
It
be
now
broad

,
but

be
cold
,
a

be

in

-

,
drink
hot

,
and
smoking

,
and
plan

for
to

.
  
<EOS>
Hugh
and

be
know

,
be
receive
with
signal

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
the
room
-
door
be
close
and

to
keep
intruder
at

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

have
take

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
Several

;

have

,

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
let

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
a

.

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
if

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
none

.
 
<EOS>
He
be

.
 
<EOS>
Oaths
,

,

,
be

.
 
<EOS>
some

if

,

;
some
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
one

cry

,
"
who
will

to
Newgate
!
"
<EOS>
and

be
a

and

towards

.
  
<EOS>
but
Hugh
and

stand

against

,
and

,
until

have

that

,

that

,
in

,

;
and

and

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
We

;

!
 
<EOS>
here
!
"
he

,
catch

's

.
 
<EOS>
"

man

,

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
out
of

,
and
not

leave

!
 
<EOS>
who
join
?
"
  
<EOS>
every
man
there
.
 
<EOS>
and
they
swear
a
great

to
release
their
friend
from
Newgate
next
night
;
to
force
the
door
and
burn

;
or
perish
in

fire
themselves
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
61
    
<EOS>
on
that
same
night
---
event
so
crowd
upon
each
other
in
convulse
and
distract
time
,
that
more
than
the
stir
incident
of
a
whole
life
often
become
compress
into
the
compass
of
four
-
and
-
twenty
hour
---
on
that
same
night
,
Mr
Haredale
,
have
strongly
bind
his
prisoner
,
with
the
assistance
of
the
sexton
,
and
force
him
to
mount
his
horse
,
conduct
him
to
Chigwell
;
bent
upon
procure
a
conveyance
to
London
from
that
place
,
and
carry
him
at
once
before
a
justice
.
 
<EOS>
the
disturbed
state
of
the
town
would
be
,
he
know
,
a
sufficient
reason
for
demand
the
murderer
's
committal
to
prison
before
daybreak
,
as
no
man
could
answer
for
the
security
of
any
of
the
watch
-
house
or
ordinary
place
of
detention
;
and
to
convey
a
prisoner
through
the
street
when
the
mob
be
again
abroad
,
would
not
only
be
a
task
of
great
danger
and
hazard
,
but
would
be
to
challenge
an
attempt
at
rescue
.
 
<EOS>
direct
the
sexton
to
lead
the
horse
,
he
walk
close
by
the
murderer
's
side
,
and
in
this
order
they
reach
the
village
about
the
middle
of
the
night
.
  
<EOS>
the
people
be
all
awake
and
up
,
for
they
be
fearful
of
be
burn
in
their
bed
,
and
seek
to
comfort
and
assure
each
other
by
watch
in
company
.
 
<EOS>
a
few
of
the
stoutest
-
hearted
be
arm
and
gather
in
a
body
on
the
green
.
 
<EOS>
to
these
,
who
know
him
well
,
Mr
Haredale
address
himself
,
briefly
narrate
what
have
happen
,
and
beseech
them
to
aid
in
convey
the
criminal
to
London
before
the
dawn
of
day
.
  
<EOS>
but
not
a
man
among
them
dare
to
help
him
by
so
much
as
the
motion
of
a
finger
.
 
<EOS>
the
rioter
,
in
their
passage
through
the
village
,
have
menace
with
their
fierce
vengeance
,
any
person
who
should
aid
in
extinguish
the
fire
,
or
render
the
least
assistance
to
him
,
or
any
catholic
whomsoever
.
 
<EOS>
Their
threat
extend
to
their
life
and
all
they
possess
.
 
<EOS>
They
be
assemble
for
their
own
protection
,
and
could
not
endanger
themselves
by
lend
any
aid
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
this
they
tell
him
,
not
without
hesitation
and
regret
,
as
they
keep
aloof
in
the
moonlight
and
glance
fearfully
at
the
ghostly
rider
,
who
,
with
his
head
droop
on
his
breast
and
his
hat
slouch
down
upon
his
brow
,
neither
move
nor
speak
.
  
<EOS>
find
it
impossible
to
persuade
them
,
and
indeed
hardly
know
how
to
do
so
after
what
they
have
see
of
the
fury
of
the
crowd
,
Mr
Haredale
beseech
them
that
at
least
they
would
leave
him
free
to
act
for
himself
,
and
would
suffer
him
to
take
the
only
chaise
and
pair
of
horse
that
the
place
afford
.
 
<EOS>
this
be
not
accede
to
without
some
difficulty
,
but
in
the
end
they
tell
him
to
do
what
he
would
,
and
go
away
from
them
in
heaven
's
name
.
  
<EOS>
leave
the
sexton
at
the
horse
's
bridle
,
he
draw
out
the
chaise
with
his
own
hand
,
and
would
have
harness
the
horse
,
but
that
the
post
-
boy
of
the
village
---
a
soft
-
hearted
,
good
-
for
-
nothing
,
vagabond
kind
of
fellow
---
be
move
by
his
earnestness
and
passion
,
and
,
throw
down
a
pitchfork
with
which
he
be
armed
,
swear
that
the
rioter
may
cut
him
into
mincemeat
if
they
like
,
but
he
would
not
stand
by
and
see
an
honest
gentleman
who
have
do
no
wrong
,
reduce
to
such
extremity
,
without
do
what
he
could
to
help
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
shake
him
warmly
by
the
hand
,
and
thank
him
from
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
in
five
minute
'
time
the
chaise
be
ready
,
and
this
good
scapegrace
in
his
saddle
.
 
<EOS>
the
murderer
be
put
inside
,
the
blind
be
draw
up
,
the
sexton
take
his
seat
upon
the
bar
,
Mr
Haredale
mount
his
horse
and
ride
close
beside
the
door
;
and
so
they
start
in
the
dead
of
night
,
and
in
profound
silence
,
for
London
.
  
<EOS>
the
consternation
be
so
extreme
that
even
the
horse
which
have
escape
the
flame
at
the
Warren
,
could
find
no
friend
to
shelter
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
pass
them
on
the
road
,
browse
on
the
stunted
grass
;
and
the
driver
tell
them
,
that
the
poor
beast
have
wander
to
the
village
first
,
but
have
be
drive
away
,
lest
they
should
bring
the
vengeance
of
the
crowd
on
any
of
the
inhabitant
.
  
<EOS>
nor
be
this
feeling
confine
to
such
small
place
,
where
the
people
be
timid
,
ignorant
,
and
unprotected
.
 
<EOS>
when
they
come
near
London
they
meet
,
in
the
grey
light
of
morning
,
more
than
one
poor
catholic
family
who
,
terrify
by
the
threat
and
warning
of
their
neighbour
,
be
quit
the
city
on
foot
,
and
who
tell
them
they
could
hire
no
cart
or
horse
for
the
removal
of
their
good
,
and
have
be
compel
to
leave
them
behind
,
at
the
mercy
of
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
Near
Mile
End
they
pass
a
house
,
the
master
of
which
<EOS>
,
a
catholic
gentleman
of
small
mean
,
have
hire
a
waggon
to
remove
his
furniture
by
midnight
,
have
have
it
all
bring
down
into
the
street
,
to
wait
the
vehicle
's
arrival
,
and
save
time
in
the

.
 
<EOS>
but
the
man
with
whom
he
make
the
bargain
,
alarm
by
the
fire
that
night
,
and
by
the
sight
of
the
rioter
pass
his
door
,
have
refuse
to
keep
it
:
and
the
poor
gentleman
,
with
his
wife
and
servant
and
their
little
child
,
be
sit
tremble
among
their
good
in
the
open
street
,
dread
the
arrival
of
day
and
not
know
where
to
turn
or
what

do
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
the
same
,
they
hear
,
with
the
public

.
 
<EOS>
the
panic
be
so
great
that
the
mail
and
stage
-
coach
be
afraid
to
carry
passenger
who
profess

obnoxious

.
 
<EOS>
if
the
driver
know

,

,

,
no
,

;

,

have
be

,

mark

,
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
one

---
 
a

,
whose

be
destroy
;
a

---

,

.
 
<EOS>

account
they

,

<EOS>
Chapter
63
    
during
the
whole
of
this
day
,
every

in
or

the
metropolis
be
on

;

,

-
four
hour
'
journey
,
begin
to
pour
in
by
all
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
but
the
disturbance
have
attain
to
such
a
formidable
height
,
and
the
rioter
have
grow
,
with
impunity
,
to
be
so
audacious
,
that
the
sight
of
this
great
force
,
continually
augment
by
new
arrival
,
instead
of
operate
as
a
check
,
stimulate
them
to
outrage
of
great
hardihood
than
any
they
have
yet
commit
;
and
help
to
kindle
a
flame
in
London
,
the
like
of
which
have
never
be
behold
,
even
in
its
ancient
and
rebellious
time
.
  
<EOS>
all
yesterday
,
and
on
this
day
likewise
,
the
commander
-
in
-
chief
endeavour
to
arouse
the
magistrate
to
a
sense
of
their
duty
,
and
in
particular
the
Lord
Mayor
,
who
be
the
faintest
-
hearted
and
most
timid
of
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
with
this
object
,
large
body
of
the
soldiery
be
several
time
despatch
to
the
Mansion
House
to
await
his
order
:
<EOS>
but
as
he
could
,
by
no
threat
or
persuasion
,
be
induce
to
give
any
,
and
as
the
man
remain
in
the
open
street
,
fruitlessly
for
any
good
purpose
,
and
thrivingly
for
a
very
bad
one
;
these
laudable
attempt
do
harm
rather
than
good
.
 
<EOS>
for
the
crowd
,
become
speedily
acquaint
with
the
Lord
Mayor
's
temper
,
do
not
fail
to
take
advantage
of
it
by
boast
that
even
the
civil
authority
be
oppose
to
the
Papists
,
and
could
not
find
it
in
their
heart
to
molest
those
who
be
guilty
of
no
other
offence
.
 
<EOS>
these
vaunt
they
take
care
to
make
within
the
hearing
of
the
soldier
;
and
<EOS>
they
,
be
naturally
loth
to
quarrel
with
the
people
,
receive
their
advance
kindly
enough
:
answer
,
when
they
be
ask
if
they
desire
to
fire
upon
their
countryman
,
"
no
,
they
would
be
damn
if
they
do
;
"
and
show
much
honest
simplicity
and
good
nature
.
 
<EOS>
the
feeling
that
the
military
be
no
-
popery
man
,
and
be
ripe
for
disobey
order
and
join
the
mob
,
soon
become
very
prevalent
in
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
Rumours
of
their
disaffection
,
and
of
their
lean
towards
the
popular
cause
,
spread
from
mouth
to
mouth
with
astonishing
rapidity
;
and
whenever
they
be
draw
up
idly
in
the
street
or
square
,
there
be
sure
to
be
a
crowd
about
them
,
cheer
and
shake
hand
,
and
treat
them
with
a
great
show
of
confidence
and
affection
.
  
<EOS>
by
this
time
,
the
crowd
be
everywhere
;
all
concealment
and
disguise
be
lay
aside
,
and
they
pervade
the
whole
town
.
 
<EOS>
if
any
man
among
them
want
money
,
he
have
but
to
knock
at
the
door
of
a
dwelling
-
house
,
or
walk
into
a
shop
,
and
demand
it
in
the
rioter
name
;
and
his
demand
be
instantly
comply
with
.
 
<EOS>
the
peaceable
citizen
be
afraid
to
lay
hand
upon
them
,
singly
and
alone
,
it
may
be
easily
suppose
that
when
gather
together
in
body
,
they
be
perfectly
secure
from
interruption
.
 
<EOS>
They
assemble
in
the
street
,
traverse
them
at
their
will
and
pleasure
,
and
publicly
concert
their
plan
.
 
<EOS>
business
be
quite
suspend
;
the
great
part
of
the
shop
be
close
;
most
of
the
house
display
a
blue
flag
in
token
of
their
adherence
to
the
popular
side
;
and
even
the
Jews
in
Houndsditch
,
Whitechapel
,
and
those
quarter
,
write
upon
their
door
or
window
-
shutter
,
"
this
House
be
a
True
Protestant
.
<EOS>
"
the
crowd
be
the
law
,
and
never
be
the
law
hold
in
great
dread
,
or
more
implicitly
obey
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
about
six
o'clock
in
the
evening
,
when
a
vast
mob
pour
into
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
by
every
avenue
,
and
divide
---
evidently
in
pursuance
of
a
previous
design
---
into
several
party
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
understand
that
this
arrangement
be
know
to
the
whole
crowd
,
but
that
it
be
the
work
of
a
few
leader
;
who
,
mingle
with
the
man
as
they
come
upon
the
ground
,
and
call
to
them
to
fall
into
this
or
that
parry
,
effect

as
rapidly
as
if
it
have
be
determine
on
by
a
council
of
the
whole
number
,
and
every
man
have
know
his
place
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
perfectly
notorious
to
the
assemblage
that
the
large
body
,
which
comprehend
about
two
-
third
of
the
whole
,
be
design
for
the
attack
on
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
It
comprehend
all
the
rioter
who
have
be
conspicuous
in
any
of
their
former
proceeding
;
all
those
whom
they
recommend
as
daring
hand
and
fit
for
the
work
;
all
those
whose
companion
have
be
take
in
the
riot
;
and
a
great
number
of
people
who
be
relative
or
friend
of
felon
in
the
jail
.
 
<EOS>
this
last
class
include
,
not
only
the
most
desperate
and
utterly
abandon
villain
in
London
,
but
some
who
be
comparatively
innocent
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
more
than
one
woman
there
,
disguise
in
man
's
attire
,
and
bent
upon
the
rescue
of
a
child
or
brother
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
the
two
son
of
a
man
who
lie
under
sentence
of
death
,
and
who
be
to
be
execute
along
with
three
other
,
on
the
next
day
but
one
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
a
great
parry
of
boy
whose
fellow
-
pickpocket
be
in
the
prison
;
and
at
the
skirt
of
all
,
a
score
of
miserable
woman
,
outcast
from

,
seek
to
release
some
other
fall
creature
as

as

,
or
move
by
a
general
sympathy
perhaps
---
God
know
---
with
all
who
be
without
hope
,
and
wretched
.
  
<EOS>
old
sword
,
and
pistol
without
ball
or
powder
;
sledge
-
hammer
,

,
axis
,
saw
,
and
weapon
pillage
from
the
butcher
'

;
a
forest
of
iron

and
wooden
club
<EOS>
;
long
ladder
for
scale
the
wall
,
each

on

of

dozen
man
;
light

;
tow
smear
with
pitch
,
and
tar
,
and

;
stave
roughly

from
fence
and
paling
;
and
even
crutch
take
from

in

;
compose
their
arm
.
 
<EOS>
when
all
be
ready
,
Hugh
and
Dennis
,
with
Simon
Tappertit
between

,
lead

.
 
<EOS>
roar
and
chafe
like
an
angry
sea
,
the
crowd
press
after
them
.
  
<EOS>
instead
of
go

down
Holborn
to

,
as

,
their

take
the
way
to
Clerkenwell
,
and
pour
down
a
quiet
street
,
halt
before
a
locksmith
's
house
---
the
Golden
Key
.
  
<EOS>
"
beat
at
the
door
,
"
cry

to
the
man
about

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
want
one
of
his
craft
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
beat
it
in
,
if
no

answer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
the
shop
be

.
 
<EOS>
both
door
and
shutter
be
of
a
strong
and

,
and

knock
without

.
 
<EOS>
but
the

raise

"
Set

house
!
"
<EOS>
and
torch
be
pass
to

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
what

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
where
be

daughter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
"
<EOS>

,

"
<EOS>
ay

.
 
<EOS>

---
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
there

.
 
<EOS>
Begone
!
<EOS>

's

!
 
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Will

?
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will

,

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>

I

,
"

<EOS>
"

!
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
"
<EOS>

,
in

make

---
 
present
,

,
a

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
the

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

;
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
snatch

,

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
there

,

,

cry
,
"
be
Simmun
below
!
"
<EOS>
at

,

,

,

,
"

!
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

Simmun
---
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"
<EOS>

;
"

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
G
Varden
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
simmun

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
the

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
---

,

.
 
<EOS>
Simmun

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

"

,

,

!
"
  
<EOS>

in

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

(

)
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
but
Gabriel
be

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

,
"
who

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

I

;
and

He
have
make

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
and

game

you

,
"

Dennis
,

;
"

.
 
<EOS>
what
be

,
brother
,
whether

Akerman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
hear
no
more
from
any
of
you
,
"
reply
the
governor
,
turn
towards
the
speaker
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
but
I
be
not
one
of
them
,
"
say

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
an
honest
man
,
Mr
Akerman
;
a

---
Gabriel
Varden
,
the
locksmith
.
<EOS>
You
know
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
You
among
the
crowd
!
"
cry

governor
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
bring
here
by
force
---
bring
here
to
pick

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
bear

,
Mr
Akerman
<EOS>
,

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
if

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
be

way
(
if

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
none
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
once

,

robber

,
"

,

,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
ah
!
 
<EOS>
Howl
<EOS>
till

.
 
<EOS>
I
refuse
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
stay
---

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Varden
,

for

,

<EOS>
"
  
"

,

"

,

be

,

,

,
an

,

;
"
upon

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
where

man
,
"

keeper
,

"
who

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
here
!
"
<EOS>
Hugh
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"

the

of

be
,

that
by

that

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

"

?
 
<EOS>

's

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
be
that
fair
,
lad
?
"
  
<EOS>
the

reply

with

!
  
<EOS>
"
You
see

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
keep
'em

,
in
King
George
's

.
 
<EOS>

have

.
 
<EOS>
good

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
there
be
no
more

.
 
<EOS>
a

of
stone
and
other
missile
compel
the
keeper
of
the
jail
to
retire
;
and
the
mob
,
press
on
,
and
swarm
round
the
wall
,
force
Gabriel
Varden
close
up
to
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
in
vain
the
basket
of
tool
be
lay
upon
the
ground
before
him
,
and
he
be
urge
in
turn
by

,
by

,
by

of

,
and

instant

,
to
do

office
for
which

have
bring

there
.
 
<EOS>
"
no
,
"
cry
the
sturdy
locksmith
,
"
I
will
not
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
have
never
love
his
life
so
well
as
then
,
but
nothing
could
move
him
.
 
<EOS>
the
savage
face
that
glare
upon
him
,
look
where
he
would
;
the
cry
of
those
who
thirst
,
like
wild
animal
,
for
his
blood
;
the
sight
of
man
press
forward
,
and
trample
down
their
fellow
,
as
they
strove
to
reach
him
,
and
strike
at
him
above
the
head
of
other
man
,
with
axis
and
with
iron
bar
;
all
fail
to
daunt

.
 
<EOS>
He
look
from
man
to
man
,
and
face
to

,
and
still
,
with
quicken

and
lessening

,
cry

,
"
I
will
not
!
"
  
<EOS>
Dennis
deal
him
a
blow
upon
the
face
which
fell
him
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
He
spring
up
again
like
a
man
in
the
prime
of
life
,
and
with
blood
upon
his
forehead
,
catch
him
by

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
cowardly
dog
!
"
<EOS>
he
say
:
"
give
me
my
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
give
me
my
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
struggle
together
.
 
<EOS>
some

"
kill
him
,
"
and
some
(
but
they
be
not
near
enough
)
strove
to

to

.
 
<EOS>
Tug
as
he
would
at
the
old

's

,
the

could
not

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
be
this
all

return
you

,
you

?
"
<EOS>
he
articulate
with
great

,
and

many

.
  
<EOS>
"
give
me
my
daughter
!
"
<EOS>
cry
the
locksmith
,
who
be
now
as

as
those
who
gather

:
"
give
me
my
daughter
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
be
down
again
,
and
up
,
and
down

,
and
buffet
with

,

,
when

,
fresh

,

smoke

,

-

,

,
aim

old

's

.
<EOS>
at
that

,
and
in

,

,
as

by

,
and
over

a
one

come

's

.
 
<EOS>
another

be

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
leave

to
us
!
"
<EOS>
they

Hugh
---
struggle
,

,

force

.
 
<EOS>
"
leave
him
to
us
.
<EOS>
why

such
as
he
,

!
 
<EOS>
You
lose

.
 
<EOS>
remember
the
prisoner
!
<EOS>
remember
Barnaby
!
"
  
<EOS>
the
cry
run
through

mob
.
 
<EOS>
Hammers
begin
to
rattle
on
the
wall
;
and
every
man
strove
to
reach
the
prison
,
and
be
among
the
foremost
rank
.
 
<EOS>
fight
their
way
through
the
press
and

,
as
desperately
as
if
they
be
in
the
midst
of
enemy
rather
than

,
the

man
retreat
with

locksmith
between

,
and
drag

through
the
very
heart
of
the
concourse
.
  
<EOS>
and
now
the
stroke
begin
to
fall
like
hail
upon
the
gate
,
and
on
the
strong
building
;
for
those
who
could
not
reach
the
door
,
spend
their
fierce
rage
on
anything
---
even
on
the
great
block
of
stone
,
which
shiver

into

,
and
make

to
tingle
as
if
the
wall
be
active
in

,
and
deal

back
their

.
 
<EOS>
the
clash
of
iron
ringing
upon
iron
,
mingle
with
the
deafen
tumult
and
sound
high
above
it
,
as

great
sledge
-

rattle
on
the
nail
and
plate
door
<EOS>
:
the
sparks
fly
off
in

;
man
work
in
gang
,
and
at
short
interval
relieve
each
other
,
that
all

strength
may
be
devote
to
the
work
;
but
there
stand
the
portal
still
,
as
grim
and
dark
and
strong
as
ever
,
and
,
save
for

dint
upon

,
quite

.
  
<EOS>
while
some
bring
all
their
energy
to
bear
upon
this
toilsome

;
and
some
,
rear
ladder
against
the
prison
,
try
to

to
the
summit
of
the
wall
they
be
too
short
to

;
and
some
again
engage

of
police
a

,
and
beat

back
and
tread
them
under
foot
by
force
of
number
;
other
besiege
the
house
on
which
the
jailer
have
appear
,
and
drive
in
the
door
,
bring
out
his
furniture
,
and
pile
it
up
against
the
prison
-
gate
,
to
make

which
should
burn

down
.
 
<EOS>
as
soon
as
this
device
be
understand
,
all
those
who
have
labour
hitherto
,
cast
down

tool
and
help
to
swell

heap
;
which
reach
half
-
way
across
the
street
,
and
be
so
high
,
that
those
who
throw
more
fuel
on
the
top
,
get
up
by
ladder
.
 
<EOS>
when
all
the
keeper
's
good
be
fling
upon
this
costly
pile
,
to
the
last
fragment
,
they
smear
it
with
the
pitch
,
and
tar
,
and
rosin
they
have
bring
,
and
sprinkle
it
with
turpentine
.
 
<EOS>
to
all
the
woodwork
round
the
prison
-
door
<EOS>
they
do
the
like
,
leave
not
a
joist
or
beam
untouched
.
 
<EOS>
this
infernal
christening
perform
,
they
fire
the
pile
with
light

and
with
blaze
tow
,
and
then
stand
by
,
await
the
result
.
  
<EOS>
the
furniture
be
very
dry
,
and
render
more
combustible
by
wax
and
oil
,
besides
the
art
they
have
use
,
take
fire
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
the
flame
roar
high
and
fiercely
,
blacken
the
prison
-
wall
,
and
twine
up
its
loftly
front
like
burn
serpent
.
 
<EOS>
at
first
they
crowd
round
the
blaze
,
and
vent
their
exultation
only
in
their
look
:
but
when
it
grow
hot
and
fiercer
---
when
it
crackle
,
leap
,
and
roar
,
like
a
great
furnace
---
when
it
shine
upon
the
opposite
house
,
and
light
up
not
only
the
pale
and
wonder
face
at
the
window
,
but
the
inmost
corner
of
each
habitation
---
 
when
through
the
deep
red
heat
and
glow
,
the
fire
be
see
sport
and
toy
with
the
door
,
now
cling
to
its
obdurate
surface
,
now
glide
off
with
fierce
inconstancy
and
soar
high
into
the
sky
,
anon
return
to
fold
it
in
its
burn
grasp
and
lure
it
to
its
ruin
---
when
it
shine
and
gleam
so
brightly
that
the
church
clock
of
St
Sepulchre
's
so
often
point
to
the
hour
of
death
,
be
legible
as
in
broad
day
,
and
the
vane
upon
its
steeple
-
top
glitter
in
the
unwonted
light
like
something
richly
jewel
---
 
when
blacken
stone
and
sombre
brick
grow
ruddy
in
the
deep
reflection
,
and
window
shine
like
burnished
gold
,
dot
the
long
distance
in
the
fiery
vista
with
their
speck
of
brightness
---
when
wall
and
tower
,
and
roof
and
chimney
-
stack
,
seem
drunk
,
and
in
the
flicker
glare
appear
to
reel
and
stagger
---
 
<EOS>
when
score
of
object
,
never
see
before
,
burst
out
upon
the
view
,
and
thing
the
most
familiar
put
on
some
new
aspect
---
then
the
mob
begin
to
join
the
whirl
,
and
with
loud
yell
,
and
shout
,
and
clamour
,
such
as
happily
be
seldom
hear
,
bestir
themselves
to
feed
the
fire
,
and
keep
it
at
its
height
.
  
<EOS>
although
the
heat
be
so
intense
that
the
paint
on
the
house
over
against
the
prison
,
parch
and
crackle
up
,
and
swell
into
boil
,
as
it
be
from
excess
of
torture
,
break
and
crumble
away
;
although
the
glass
fall
from
the
window
-
sash
,
and
the
lead
and
iron
on
the
roof
blister
the
incautious
hand
that
touch
them
,
and
the
sparrow
in
the
eave
take
wing
,
and
render
giddy
by
the
smoke
,
fall
flutter
down
upon
the
blaze
pile
;
still
the
fire
be
tend
unceasingly
by
busy
hand
,
and
round
it
,
man
be
go
always
.
 
<EOS>
They
never
slacken
in
their
zeal
,
or
keep
aloof
,
but
press
upon
the
flame
so
hard
,
that
those
in
front
have
much
ado
to
save
themselves
from
be
thrust
in
;
if
one
man
swoon
or
drop
,
a
dozen
struggle
for
his
place
,
and
that
although
they
know
the
pain
,
and
thirst
,
and
pressure
to
be
unendurable
.
 
<EOS>
those
who
fall
down
in
fainting
-
fit
,
and
be
not
crush
or
burn
,
be
carry
to
an
inn
-
yard
close
at
hand
,
and
dash
with
water
from
a
pump
;
of
which
bucket
full
be
pass
from
man
to
man
among
the
crowd
;
but
such
be
the
strong
desire
of
all
to
drink
,
and
such
the
fighting
to
be
first
,
that
,
for
the
most
part
,
the
whole
content
be
spill
upon
the
ground
,
without
the
lip
of
one
man
be
moisten
.
  
<EOS>
meanwhile
,
and
in
the
midst
of
all
the
roar
and
outcry
,
those
who
be
near
to
the
pile
,
heap
up
again
the
burn
fragment
that
come
topple
down
,
and
rake
the
fire
about
the
door
,
which
,
although
a
sheet
of
flame
,
be
still
a
door
fast
lock
and
bar
,
and
keep
them
out
.
 
<EOS>
great
piece
of
blaze
wood
be
pass
,
besides
,
above
the
people
's
head
to
such
as
stand
about
the
ladder
,
and
some
of
these
,
climb
up
to
the
topmost
stave
,
and
hold
on
with
one
hand
by
the
prison
wall
,
exert
all
their
skill
and
force
to
cast
these
fire
-
brand
on
the
roof
,
or
down
into
the
yard
within
.
 
<EOS>
in
many
instance
their
effort
be
successful
;
which
occasion
a
new
and
appalling
addition
to
the
horror
of
the
scene
:
for
the
prisoner
within
,
see
from
between
their
bar
that
the
fire
catch
in
many
place
and
thrive
fiercely
,
and
be
all
lock
up
in
strong
cell
for
the
night
,
begin
to
know
that
they
be
in
danger
of
be
burn
alive
.
 
<EOS>
this
terrible
fear
,
spread
from
cell
to
cell
and
from
yard
to
yard
,
vent
itself
in
such

and

,
and
in
such
dreadful
shriek
for
help
,
that
the
whole
jail
resound
with
the
noise
;
which
be
loudly
hear
even
above
the
shouting
of
the
mob
and
roaring
of
the
flame
,
and
be
so
full
of
agony
and
despair
,
that
it
make
the
bold
tremble
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
remarkable
that
these
cry
begin
in
that

of
the

front

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
judge

<EOS>

<EOS>
a

!
 
<EOS>

!

<EOS>
Chapter
65
    
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
by

bye

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
Anon
some

,

---
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
all

,
and
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

say
or
think
,
and
that
he
have
a
fear
of
go
mad
.
  
<EOS>
the
distiller
live
,
as
he
have
tell

when

,
on

,
where
he
have
great

and

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

;

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
the

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
these

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
67
    
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
sleep

.
 
<EOS>
the

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;

.

.

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,
turn
them
into
the
street
,
where
they
wander
up
and
down
hardly
remember
the
way
untrodden
by
their
foot
so
long
,
and
crying
---
<EOS>
such
abject
thing
those
rotten
-
hearted
jail
have
make
them
---
as
they
slink
off
in
their
rag
,
and
drag
their
slipshod
foot
along
the
pavement
.
  
<EOS>
even
of
the
three
hundred
prisoner
who
have
escape
from
Newgate
,
there
be
some
---
a
few
,
but
there
be
some
---
who
seek
their
jailer
out
and
deliver
themselves
up
:
prefer
imprisonment
and
punishment
to
the
horror
of
such
another
night
as
the
last
.
<EOS>
many
of
the
convict
,
draw
back
to
their
old
place
of
captivity
by
some
indescribable
attraction
,
or
by
a
desire
to
exult
over
it
in
its
downfall
and
glut
their
revenge
by
see
it
in
ashe
,
actually
go
back
in
broad
noon
,
and
loiter
about
the
cell
.
 
<EOS>
fifty
be
retake
at
one
time
on
this
next
day
,
within
the
prison
wall
;
but
their
fate
do
not
deter
other
,
for
there
they
go
in
spite
of
everything
,
and
there
they
be
take
in
two
and
three
,
twice
or
thrice
a
day
,
all
through
the
week
.
 
<EOS>
of
the
fifty
<EOS>
just
mention
,
some
be
occupy
in
endeavour
to
rekindle
the
fire
;
but
in
general
they
seem
to
have
no
object
in
view
but
to
prowl
and
lounge
about
the
old
place
:
be
often
find
asleep
in
the
ruin
,
or
sit
talk
there
,
or
even
eat
and
drink
,
as
in
a
choice
retreat
.
  
<EOS>
besides
the
notice
on
the
gate
of
the
Fleet
and
the
King
's
Bench
,
many
similar
announcement
be
leave
,
before
one
o'clock
at
noon
,
at
the
house
of
private
individual
;
and
further
,
the
mob
proclaim
their
intention
of
seize
on
the
Bank
,
the
Mint
,
the
Arsenal
at
Woolwich
,
and
the
Royal
Palaces
.
 
<EOS>
the
notice
be
seldom
deliver
by
more
than
one
man
,
who
,
if
it
be
at
a
shop
,
go
in
,
and
lay
it
,
with
a
bloody
threat
perhaps
,
upon
the
counter
;
or
if
it
be
at
a
private
house
,
knock
at
the
door
,
and
thrust
it
in
the
servant
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
notwithstanding
the
presence
of
the
military
in
every
quarter
of
the
town
,
and
the
great
force
in
the
Park
,
these
messenger
do
their
errand
with
impunity
all
through
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
so
do
two
boy
who
go
down
Holborn
alone
,
arm
with
bar
take
from
the
railing
of
Lord
Mansfield
's
house
,
and
demand
money
for
the
rioter
.
 
<EOS>
so
do
a
tall
man
on
horseback
who
make
a
collection
for
the
same
purpose
in
Fleet
Street
,
and
refuse
to
take
anything
but
gold
.
  
<EOS>
a
rumour
have
now
get
into
circulation
,
too
,
which
diffuse
a
great
dread
all
through
London
,
even
than
these
publicly
announce
intention
of
the
rioter
,
though
all
man
know
that
if
they
be
successfully
effect
,
there
must
ensue
a
national
bankruptcy
and
general
ruin
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
say
that
they
mean
to
throw
the
gate
of
Bedlam
open
,
and
let
all
the
madman
loose
.
 
<EOS>
this
suggest
such
dreadful
image
to
the
people
's
mind
,
and
be
indeed
an
act
so
fraught
with
new
and
unimaginable
horror
in
the
contemplation
,
that
it
beset
them
more
than
any
loss
or
cruelty
of
which
they
could
foresee
the
bad
,
and
drive
many
sane
man
nearly
mad
themselves
.
  
<EOS>
so
the
day
pass
on
:
the
prisoner
move
their
good
;
people
run
to
and
fro
in
the
street
,
carry
away
their
property
;
group
stand
in
silence
round
the
ruin
;
all
business
suspend
;
and
the
soldier
dispose
as
have
be
already
mention
,
remain
quite
inactive
.
 
<EOS>
so
the
day
pass
on
,
and
dread
night
draw
near
again
.
  
<EOS>
at
last
,
at
seven
o'clock
in
the
evening
,
the
Privy
Council
issue
a
solemn
proclamation
that
it
be
now
necessary
to
employ
the
military
,
and
that
the
officer
have
most

and

order
,
by
an
immediate

of
their
utmost
force
,
to
repress
the

;
and
warn
all
good
subject
of
the
King
to
keep
themselves
,
their
servant
,
and
apprentice
,
within
door
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
there
be
then
deliver
out
to
every
soldier
on
duty
,
thirty
-
six
round
of
powder
and
ball
;
the
drum
beat
;
and
the
whole
force
be
under
arm
at
sunset
.
  
<EOS>
the
City
authority
,
stimulate
by
these
vigorous
measure
,
hold
a
Common
Council
;
pass
a
vote
thank
the
military
association
who
have
tender
their
aid
to
the
civil
authority
;
accept
it
;
and
place
them
under
the
direction
of
the
two

.
 
<EOS>
at
the
Queen
's
palace
,
a
double
guard
,
the
yeoman
on
duty
,
the
groom
-
porter
,
and
all
other
attendant
,
be
station
in
the
passage
and
on
the
staircase
at
seven
o'clock
,
with
strict
instruction
to
be
watchful
on
their
post
all
night
;
and
all
the
door
be
lock
.
 
<EOS>
the
gentleman
of
the
Temple
,
and
the
other
Inns
,
mount
guard
within
their
gate
,
and
strengthen
them
with
the
great
stone
of
the
pavement
,
which
they
take
up
for
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
they
give
up
the
hall
and
common
to
the
Northumberland
Militia
,
under
the
command
of
Lord
Algernon
Percy
;
in
some
few
of
the
city
ward
,
the
burgess
turn
out
,
and
without
make
a
very
fierce
show
,
look
brave
enough
.
 
<EOS>
some
hundred
of
stout
gentleman
throw
themselves
,
arm
to
the
tooth
,
into
the
hall
of
the
different
company
,
double
-
lock
and
bolt
all
the
gate
,
and
dare
the
rioter
(
among
themselves
)
to
come
on
at
their
peril
.
 
<EOS>
these
arrangement
be
all
make
simultaneously
,
or
nearly
so
,
be
complete
by
the
time
it
get
dark
;
and
then
the
street
be
comparatively
clear
,
and
be
guard
at
all
the
great
corner
and
chief
avenue
by
the
troop
:
while
party
of
the
officer
ride
up
and
down
in
all
direction
,
order
chance
straggler
home
,
and
admonish
the
resident
to
keep
within
their
house
,
and
,
if
any
firing
ensue
,
not
to
approach
the
window
.
<EOS>
More
chain
be
draw
across
such
of
the
thoroughfare
as
be
of
a
nature
to
favour
the
approach
of
a
great
crowd
,
and
at
each
of
these
point
a
considerable
force
be
station
.
 
<EOS>
all
these
precaution
have
be
take
,
and
it
be
now
quite
dark
,
those
in
command
await
the
result
in
some
anxiety
:
and
not
without
a
hope
that
such
vigilant
demonstration
may
of
themselves
dishearten
the

,
and
prevent
any
new

.
  
<EOS>
but
in
this
reckoning
they
be
cruelly
mistaken
,
for
in
half
an
hour
,
or
less
,
as
though
the
setting
in
of
night
have
be
their
preconcerte
signal
,
the
rioter
have
previously
,
in
small
party
,
<EOS>
prevent
the
lighting
of
the
street
lamp
,
rise
like
a
great
sea
;
and
that
in
so
many
place
at
once
,
and
with
such
inconceivable
fury
,
that
those
who
have
the
direction
of
the
troop
know
not
,
at
first
,
where

turn
or
what
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
one
after
another
,
new
fire
blaze
up
in
every
quarter
of
the
town
,
as
though
it
be
the
intention
of
the
insurgent
to
wrap
the
city
in
a
circle
of
flame
,
which
,
contract
by
degree
,
should
burn
the
whole
to
ashe
;
the
crowd
swarm
and
roar
in
every
street
;
and
none
but
rioter
and
soldier
be
out
of
door
,
it
seem
to
the
latter
as
if
all
London
be
array
against
them
,
and
they
stand
alone
against
the
town
.
  
<EOS>
in
two
hour
,
six
-
and
-
thirty
fire
be
rage
---
six
-
and
-
thirty
great
conflagration
:
among
them
the
Borough
Clink
in
Tooley
Street
,
the
King
's
Bench
,
the
Fleet
,
and
the
New
Bridewell
.
 
<EOS>
in
almost
every
street
,
there
be
a
battle
;
and
in
every
quarter
the
musket
of
the
troop
be
hear
above
the
shout
and
tumult
of
the
mob
.
 
<EOS>
the
firing
begin
in
the
Poultry
,
where
the
chain
be
draw
across
the
road
,
where
nearly
a
score
of
people
be
kill
on
the
first

.
 
<EOS>
Their
body
have
be
hastily
carry
into
St
Mildred
's
Church
by
the
soldier
,
the
latter
fire
again
,
and
follow
fast
upon
the
crowd
,
who
begin
to
give
way
when
they
see
the
execution
that
be
do
,
form
across
Cheapside
,
and
charge
them
at
the
point
of
the
bayonet
.
  
<EOS>
the
street
be
now
a
dreadful
spectacle
.
 
<EOS>
the
shout
of
the
rabble
,
the
shriek
of
woman
,
the
cry
of
the
wound
,
and
the
constant
firing
,
form
a
deafening
and
an
awful
accompaniment
to
the
sight
which
every
corner
present
.
 
<EOS>
wherever
the
road
be
obstruct
by
the
chain
,
<EOS>
there
the
fighting
and
the
loss
of
life
be
great
;
but
there
be
hot
work
and
bloodshe
in
almost
every
lead
thoroughfare
.
  
<EOS>
at
Holborn
Bridge
,
and
on
Holborn
Hill
,
the
confusion
be
great
than
in
any
other
part
;
for
the
crowd
that
pour
out
of
the
city
in
two
great
stream
,
one
by
Ludgate
Hill
,
and
one
by
Newgate
Street
,
unite
at
that
spot
,
and
form
a
mass
so
dense
,
that
at
every

the
people
seem
to
fall
in
heap
.
 
<EOS>
at
this
place
a
large
detachment
of
soldiery
be
post
,
who
fire
,
now
up
<EOS>
Fleet
Market
,
now
up
Holborn
,
now
up
<EOS>
Snow
Hill
---
constantly
rake
the
street
in
each
direction
.
 
<EOS>
at
this
place
too
,
several
large
fire
be
burn
,
so
that
all
the
terror
of
that
terrible
night
seem
to
be
concentrate
in
one
spot
.
  
<EOS>
full
twenty
time
,
the
rioter
,
head
by
one
man
who
wield
an
axe
in
his
right
hand
,
and
bestrode
a
brewer
's
horse
of
great
size
and
strength
,
caparison
with
fetter
take
out
of
Newgate
,
which
clank
and
jingle
as
he
go
,
make
an
attempt
to
force
a
passage
at
this
point
,
and
fire
the
vintner
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
full
twenty
time
they
be
repulse
with
loss
of
life
,
and
still
come
back
again
;
and
though
the
fellow
at
their
head
be
mark
and
single
out
by
all
,
and
be
a
conspicuous
object
as
the
only
rioter
on
horseback
,
not
a
man
could
hit
him
.
 
<EOS>
so
surely
as
the
smoke
clear
away
,
so
surely
there
be
he
;
call
hoarsely
to
his
companion
,
brandish
his
axe
above
his
head
,
and
dash
on
as
though
he
bear
a
charm
life
,
and
be
proof
against
ball
and
powder
.
  
<EOS>
this
man
be
Hugh
;
and
in
every
part
of
the
riot
,
he
be
see
.
 
<EOS>
He
head
two
attack
upon
the
Bank
,
help
to
break
open
the
Toll
-
house
on
Blackfriars
Bridge
,
and
cast
the
money
into
the
street
:
fire
two
of
the
prison
with
his
own
hand
:
be
here
,
and
there
,
and
everywhere
---
always
foremost
---
always
active
---
strike
at
the
soldier
,
cheer
on
the
crowd
,
make
his
horse
's
iron
music
hear
through
all
the
yell
and
uproar
:
but
never
hurt
or
stop
.
<EOS>
turn
him
at
one
place
,
and
he
make
a
new
struggle
in
anotlter
;
force
him
to
retreat
at
this
point
,
and
he
advance
on
that
,
directly
.
 
<EOS>
drive
from
Holborn
for
the
twentieth
time
,
he
ride
at
the
head
of
a
great
crowd
straight
upon
Saint
Paul
's
,
attack
a
guard
of
soldier
who
keep
watch
over
a
body
of
prisoner
within
the
iron
railing
,
force
them
to
retreat
,
rescue
the
man
they
have
in
custody
,
and
with
this
accession
to
his
party
,
come
back
again
,
mad
with
liquor
and
excitement
,
and
halloo
them
on
like
a
demon
.
  
<EOS>
It
would
have
be
no
easy
task
for
the
most
careful
rider
to
sit
a
horse
in
the
midst
of
such
a
throng
and
tumult
;
but
though
this
madman
roll
upon
his
back
(
he
have
no
saddle
)
like
a
boat
upon
the
sea
,
he
never
for
an
instant
lose
his
seat
,
or
fail
to
guide
him
where
he
would
.
 
<EOS>
through
the
very
thickest
of
the
press
,
over
dead
body
and
burn
fragment
,
now
on
the
pavement
,
now
in
the
road
,
now
ride
up
a
flight
of
step
to
make
himself
the
more
conspicuous
to
his
party
,
and
now
force
a
passage
through
a
mass
of
human
being
,
so
closely
squeeze
together
that
it
seem
as
if
the
edge
of
a
knife
would
scarcely
part
them
,
---
on
he
go
,
as
though
he
could
surmount
all
obstacle
by
the
mere
exercise
of
his
will
.
 
<EOS>
and
perhaps
his
not
be
shoot
be
in
some
degree
attributable
to
this
very
circumstance
;
for
his
extreme
audacity
,
and
the
conviction
that
he
must
be
one
of
those
to
whom
the
proclamation
refer
,
inspire
the
soldier
with
a
desire
to
take
him
alive
,
and
divert
many
an
aim
which
otherwise
may
have
be
more
near
the
mark
.
  
<EOS>
the
vintner
and
Mr
Haredale
,
unable
to
sit
quietly
listen
to
the
noise
without
see
what
go
on
,
have
climb
to
the
roof
of
the
house
,
and
hide
behind
a
stack
of
chimney
,
be
look
cautiously
down
into
the
street
,
almost
hope
that
after
so
many
repulse
the
rioter
would
be
foil
,
when
a
great
shout
proclaim
that
a
parry
be
come
round
the
other
way
;
and
the
dismal
jingling
of
those
accurse
fetter
warn
them
next
moment
that
they
too
be
lead
by
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
the
soldier
have
advance
into
Fleet
Market
and
be
disperse
the
people
there
;
so
that
they
come
on
with
hardly
any
check
,
and
be
soon
before
the

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Chapter
68
    
<EOS>
while

be

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Heaven
alone
can
tell
,

,

how
many
half
-
remembered
,
dreamy
association
of
his
mother
's
grief
and
tear
and

;
he
watch
and
tend
this
man
.
 
<EOS>
but
that
a
vague

shadowy

of
such
idea
come

on

;
that

teach

to
be

when

,

when

,

keep

in

,

from
the

,
fan

,
soothe

start

---
ah
!
<EOS>
what
a
troubled
sleep
it
be
---
and
wonder
when
she
would

to

and
be

,
be
the

.
 
<EOS>
He
sit

him
all
that

;
listen
for
her

in

,

on

gently
-

,

,

his

;

,
and
wonder

be

.
 
<EOS>
the

go

,
and

come

,
and
he
be
still

;

,

,

,

,

---
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

leave

.
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
chapter
70
    
Mr
Dennis
have

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;

;

.
  
<EOS>
have

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
73
    
<EOS>
by

---

,

.
 
<EOS>
true
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

.

;

<EOS>
this

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
nor

slow

:

,

;

,

-

,

,

'

.
  
<EOS>

,

,
Barnaby

,

,

.

,

,

.

,

,

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

:
"

,
---

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
hope
!
 
<EOS>
ay
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

.

"
<EOS>
nobody
,

,

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

.

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

You
!
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>

?
"

.

.
 
<EOS>

tooth
,
and
smile

.
  
<EOS>
"
not

,
"

;
"

,

,

<EOS>
Husband
,

;

,

<EOS>
Chapter
74
    
Me
Dennis
,

but

's

still

<EOS>
Chapter
75
    
a

,
---

.
 
<EOS>
through

<EOS>
the

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
high

,

.
  
<EOS>

.

,

.

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>

he

;
lean

"

,

!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

re

.

"

,

<EOS>

;

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

be
hang

brow
,
the

his

---

that
swallow

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
have
mark
the

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

.

"

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
see
the
hangman
when
it

!
"
<EOS>

,

---
"
<EOS>
ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
courage
,
bold
Barnaby
,
what

?
 
<EOS>
Your
hand
!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
another

!
 
<EOS>
a

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
ha
ha

!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
77
    
<EOS>
the
time
wear
on
.
 
<EOS>
the

in

less

,

,
mark

---
soft

while

---
of
that
Great

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
into

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
  
<EOS>
three

!
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

---

"

"
<EOS>

the
great
concourse
,
with
a
shriek
or
groan
---
burst
forth
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
terrible
to
see
---
if
any
one
in
that
distraction
of
excitement
could
have
see
---
the
world
of
eager
eye
,
all
strain
upon
the
scaffold
and
the
beam
.
  
<EOS>
the
hollow
murmuring
be
hear
within
the
jail
as
plainly
as
without
.
 
<EOS>
the
three
be
bring
forth
into
the
yard
,
together
,
as
it
resound
through
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
They
know
its
import
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
d'ye
hear
?
"
<EOS>
cry
Hugh
,
undaunte
by
the
sound
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
expect
us
!
<EOS>
I
hear
them
gather
when
I
wake
in
the
night
,
and
turn
over
on
t'other
side
and
fall
asleep
again
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
see
how
they
welcome
the
hangman
,
now
that
it
come
home
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
  
<EOS>
the
Ordinary
come
up
at
this
moment
,
reprove
him
for
his
indecent
mirth
,
and
advise
him
to
alter
his
demeanour
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
and
why
,
master
?
"
say
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
I
do
better
than
bear
it
easily
?
 
<EOS>
you
bear
it
easily
enough
.
 
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
never
tell
me
,
"
he
cry
,
as
the
other
would
have
speak
,
"
for
all
your
sad
look
and
your
solemn
air
,
you
think
little
enough
of
it
!
 
<EOS>
They
say
you
be
the
good
maker
of
lobster
salad
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
hear
that
,
you
see
,
before
now
.
 
<EOS>
be
it
a
good
one
<EOS>
,
this
morning
---
be
your
hand
in
?
 
<EOS>
how
do
the
breakfast
look
?
 
<EOS>
I
hope
there
be
enough
,
and
to
spare
,
for
all
this
hungry
company
that
will
sit
down
to
it
,
when
the
sight
be
over
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
,
"
observe
the
clergyman
,
shake
his
head
,
"
that
you
be
incorrigible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
be
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
be
,
"
rejoin
Hugh
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
be
no
hypocrite
,
master
!
 
<EOS>
You
make
a
merry
-
making
of
this
,
every
month
;
let
me
be
merry
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
if
you
want
a
frightened
fellow
there
be
one
that
will
suit
you
.
 
<EOS>
try
your
hand
upon
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
point
,
as
he
speak
,
to
Dennis
,
who
,
with
his
leg
trail
on
the
ground
,
be
hold
between
two
man
;
and
who
tremble
so
,
that
all
his
joint
and
limb
seem
rack
by
spasm
.
 
<EOS>
turn
from
this
wretched
spectacle
,
he
call
to
Barnaby
,
who
stand
apart
.
  
<EOS>
"
what
cheer
,
Barnaby
?
 
<EOS>
do
not
be
downcast
,
lad
.
 
<EOS>
leave
that
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
bless
you
,
"
cry
Barnaby
,
step
lightly
towards
him
,
"
I
be
not
frightened
,
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
I
be
quite
happy
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
not
desire
to
live
now
,
if
they
would
let
me
.
 
<EOS>
look
at
me
!
 
<EOS>
be
I
afraid
to
die
?
 
<EOS>
Will
they
see
me
tremble
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
gaze
for
a
moment
at
his
face
,
on
which
there
be
a
strange
,
unearthly
smile
;
and
at

eye
,
which
sparkle
brightly
;
and
interpose
between
him
and
the
ordinary
,
gruffly
whisper
to
the
latter
:
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
say
much
to
him
,
master
,
if
I
be
you
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
spoil
your
appetite
for
breakfast
,
though
you
are
used
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
be
the
only
one
of
the
three
who
have
wash
or
trim
himself
that
morning
.
 
<EOS>
neither
of
the
other
have
do
so
,
since
their
doom
be
pronounce
.
 
<EOS>
He
still
wear
the
broken
peacock
's
feather
in
his
hat
;
and
all
his
usual
scrap
of
finery
be
carefully
disposed
about
his
person
.
 
<EOS>
His
kindle
eye
,
his
firm
step
,
his
proud
and
resolute
bearing
,
may
have
grace
some
lofty
act
of
heroism
;
some
voluntary
sacrifice
,
bear
of
a
noble
cause
and
pure
enthusiasm
;
rather
than
that
felon
's
death
.
  
<EOS>
but
all
these
thing
increase
his
guilt
.
 
<EOS>
They
be
mere
assumption
.
 
<EOS>
the
law
have
declare
it
so
,
and
so
it
must
be
.
 
<EOS>
the
good
minister
have
be
greatly
shock
,
not
a
quarter
of
an
hour
before
,
at
his
parting
with
Grip
.
 
<EOS>
for
one
in
his
condition
,
to
fondle
a
bird
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
the
yard
be
fill
with
people
;
bluff
civic
functionary
,
officer
of
justice
,
soldier
,
the
curious
in
such
matter
,
and
guest
who
have
be
bid
as
to
a
wedding
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
look
about
him
,
nod
gloomily
to
some
person
in
authority
,
who
indicate
with
his
hand
in
what
direction
he
be
to
proceed
;
and
clap
Barnaby
on
the
shoulder
,
pass
out
with
the
gait
of
a
lion
.
  
<EOS>
They
enter
a
large
room
,
so
near
to
the
scaffold
that
the
voice
of
those
who
stand
about
it
,
could
be
plainly
hear
:
some
beseech
the
javelin
-
man
to
take
them
out
of
the
crowd
:
other
cry
to
those
behind
,
to
stand
back
,
for
they
be
press
to
death
,
and
suffocate
for
want
of
air
.
  
<EOS>
in
the
middle
of
this
chamber
,
two
smith
,
with
hammer
,
stand
beside
an
anvil
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
walk
straight
up
to
them
,
and
set
his
foot
upon
it
with
a
sound
as
though
it
have
be
strike
by
a
heavy
weapon
.
 
<EOS>
then
,
with
fold
arm
,
he
stand
to
have
his
iron
knock
off
:
<EOS>
scowl
haughtily
round
,
as
those
who
be
present
eyed
him
narrowly
and
whisper
to
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
It
take
so
much
time
to
drag
Dennis
in
,
that
this
ceremony
be
over
with
Hugh
,
and
nearly
over
with
Barnaby
,
before
he
appear
.
 
<EOS>
He
no
sooner
come
into
the
place
he
know
so
well
,
however
,
and
among
face
with
which
he
be
so
familiar
,
than
he
recover
strength
and
sense
enough
to
clasp
his
hand
and
make
a
last
appeal
.
  
<EOS>
"
gentleman
,
good
gentleman
,
"
cry
the
abject
creature
,
grovel
down
upon
his
knee
,
and
actually
prostrate
himself
upon
the
stone

:
"
Governor
,
dear
governor
---
honourable
sheriff
---
worthy

---
have
mercy
upon
a

man
that
have
serve
His
Majesty
,
and
the
Law
,
and
Parliament
,
for
so

,
and
do
not
---
 
<EOS>
do
not
let
me
die
---
because
of
a
mistake
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dennis
,
"
say
the
governor
of
the
jail
,
"
you
know
what
the
course
be
,
and
that
the
order
come
with
the

.
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
we
could
do
nothing
,
even
if
we
would
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
all
I
ask
,
sir
,
---
all
I
want
and
beg
,
be
time
,
to
make
it
sure
,
"
cry
the
tremble
wretch
,
look
wildly
round
for

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
the
King
and
Government
can
not
know
it
be
me
;
I
be
sure
they
can
not
know
it
be
me
;
or
they
never
would
bring
me
to
this
dreadful

.
 
<EOS>
They
know
my
name
,
but
they
do
not

be
the

.
 
<EOS>
stop

execution
---
for

's
sake
stop
my
execution
,
gentleman
---
till
they
can
be
tell
that
I
have
be
hangman
here
,
nigh
thirty

.
 
<EOS>
Will
no
one
go
and
tell

?
"
<EOS>
he
implore
,
clench

and

,
and
round
,

---
"
will
no

go

tell

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Akerman
,
"
say

,

,
"

in

a

,
even

,

that
he
be

have

,

be
consider
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
---
but

that

,
"
cry

,

,

;
"
whereas
it
be
bad
,
it
be
bad
a
hundred

,
to
me
than

.
 
<EOS>
let

,

.
 
<EOS>
let

.
 
<EOS>
They
have
make

bad
to
me
by
give

to

.
 
<EOS>
stop

till

know
that
!
"
  
<EOS>
the

beckon

,
and
the

,

have
support

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
utter

:
  
"
<EOS>
wait
!
 
<EOS>
wait
.
 
<EOS>
only

---
only

!
 
<EOS>
give

.
 
<EOS>
one

three
be
to
go
to
Bloomsbury
Square
.
<EOS>
let

be
the

.
 
<EOS>
It
may
come
in
that

;
it
be

.
<EOS>
in
the
Lord
's
name
let
me
be
send
to
Bloomsbury
Square
.
 
<EOS>
do
not
hang

here
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
murder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
take
him
to
the
anvil
:
but
even
then
he
could
he
hear
above
the
clinking
of
the
smith
'

,
and
the

raging
of
the

,
cry
that
he
know
of
Hugh
's
birth
---
that
his
father
be
live
,
and
be
a
gentleman
of
influence
and
rank
---
that
he
have
family
secret
in
his

---
that
he
could
tell
nothing
unless
they
give
him
time
,
but
must
die
with
them
on
his
mind
;
and
he
continue
to
rave
in
this

until
his
voice
fail
him
,
and
he
sink
down
a
mere

of
clothe
between

two
attendant
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
at
this

that
the
clock
strike
the
first
stroke
of

,
and
the
bell
begin
to

.
 
<EOS>
the
various
officer
,
with
the

sheriff
at

head
,
move
towards
the

.
 
<EOS>
all
be
ready
when
the
last
chime
come
upon

ear
.
  
<EOS>
They
tell
Hugh
this
,
and
ask
if
he
have
anything
to
say
.
  
<EOS>
"
to
say
!
<EOS>
"
he
cry
.
 
<EOS>
"
not
I.
 
<EOS>
I
be
ready
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
yes
,
"
he
add
,
as
his
eye
fall
upon
Barnaby
,
"
I
have
a
word
to
say
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
come
hither
,
lad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
there
be
,
for
the
moment
,
something
kind
,
and
even
tender
,
struggle
in
his
fierce
aspect
,
as
he
wring

poor
companion
by

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
say
this
,
"
he
cry
,
look

round
,
"
that
if
I
have
ten
life
to
lose
,
and
the
loss
of
each
would
give
me
ten
time
the
agony
of
the

,
I

them
all

---
<EOS>
ay
,
I

,
though
you
gentleman
may
not

---
to

.
 
<EOS>
this

,
"
he
add
,
wring

,
"
that
will
be
lose
through
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
not
through
you
,
"
say

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

not

.
 
<EOS>
You
be
not
to
blame
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
always

very
good

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Hugh
,
we
shall
know
what
make
the
star
shine
,
now
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
take
him
from
her
in
a

,
and
do

what
harm
would
come
of

,
"
say

,
lay

upon

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ask
her
pardon
;
and
his
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
look
here
,
"
he
add
roughly
,
in

former

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
this
lad
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
murmur
"
yes
,
"
and
seem
to
wonder
why
he
ask
.
  
<EOS>
"
that
gentleman
yonder
---
"
point
to
the
clergyman
---
"
have
often
in
the
last
few
day
speak
to
me
of
faith
,
and
strong
belief
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
what
I
be
---
more
brute
than
man
,
as
I
have
be
often
tell
---
<EOS>
but
I
have
faith
enough
to
believe
,
and
do

as
strongly
as
any
of
you
gentleman
can
believe
anything
,
that
this
one
life
would
be
spare
.
 
<EOS>
see
what
he
be
!
<EOS>
---
look
at
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
have
move
towards
the
door
,
and
stand
beckon
him
to
follow
.
  
<EOS>
"
if
this
be
not
faith
,
and
strong
belief
!
"
cry
Hugh
,
raise
his
right
arm
aloft
,
and
look
upward
like
a
savage
prophet
whom
the
near
approach
of
death
have
fill
with
inspiration
,
<EOS>
"
where
be
they
!
 
<EOS>
what
else
should
teach
me
---
me
,
bear
as
I
be
bear
,
and
rear
as
I
have
be
rear
---
to
hope
for
any
mercy
in
this
harden
,
cruel
,
unrelenting

!
 
<EOS>
upon
these
human
shamble
,
I
,
who
never
raise
this
hand
in
prayer
till
now
,
call
down
the
wrath
of
God
!
 
<EOS>
on
that
black
tree
,
of
which
I
be
the
ripen
fruit
,
I
do
invoke
the
curse
of
all
its
victim
,
past
,
and
present
,
and
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
on
the
head
of
that
man
,
who
,
in
his
conscience
,
own
me
for
his
son

<EOS>

,
amen
,

"

<EOS>
Chapter
79
    
Old
John
do

<EOS>
Chapter
81
    
<EOS>
another
month
have
pass
,
and
the
end
of
August
have
nearly
come
,
when
Mr
Haredale
stand
alone
in

office
at

.
<EOS>
although

week
have

with
Edward

and

,
in

's

,
and

have

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
look
much
old
,

more

-

.
 
<EOS>
agitation
and

of
mind
scatter
wrinkle
and
grey

with

;
but
deep

follow

of
old

,

dear
,

.
 
<EOS>
the

not

,
but
their

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
be
now

,
and

within

be
dreary

.
  
<EOS>
He
be

the
less
alone
for
have

.
 
<EOS>
this
be
no
well
preparation
than

:

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

---

---

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

;

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

in
London
;
and
would
spare
himself
the
pang
of
parting
,
even
with
the
honest
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
such
condition
of
the
mind
as
that
to
which
he
be
a
prey
when
he
lie
down
to
rest
,
be
favourable
to
the
growth
of
disorder
fancy
,
and
uneasy
vision
.
 
<EOS>
He
know
this
,
even
in
the
horror
with
which
he
start
from
his
first
sleep
,
and
throw
up
the
window
to
dispel
it
by
the
presence
of
some
object
,
beyond
the
room
,
which
have
not
be
,
as
it
be
,
the
witness
of
his
dream
.
 
<EOS>
but
it
be
not
a
new
terror
of
the
night
;
it
have
be
present
to
him
before
,
in
many
shape
;
it
have
haunt
him
in
bygone
time
,
and
visit
his
pillow
again
and
again
.
 
<EOS>
if
it
have
be
but
an
ugly
object
,
a
childish
spectre
,
haunt
his
sleep
,
its
return
,
in
its
old
form
,
may
have
awaken
a
momentary
sensation
of
fear
,
which
,
almost
in
the
act
of
wake
,
would
have
pass
away
.
 
<EOS>
this
disquiet
,
however
,
linger
about
him
,
and
would
yield
to
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
when
he
close
his
eye
again
,
he
feel
it
hover
near
;
as
he
slowly
sink
into
a
slumber
,
he
be
conscious
of
its
gathering
strength
and
purpose
,
and
gradually
assume
its
recent
shape
;
when
he
spring
up
from
his
bed
,
the
same
phantom
vanish
from
his
heated
brain
,
and
leave
him
fill
with
a
dread
against
which
reason
and
wake
thought
be
powerless
.
  
<EOS>
the
sun
be
up
,
before
he
could
shake
it
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
rise
late
,
but
not
refresh
,
and
remain
within
door
all
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
have
a
fancy
for
pay
his
last
visit
to
the
old
spot
in
the
evening
,
for
he
have
be
accustom
to
walk
there
at
that
season
,
and
desire
to
see
it
under
the
aspect
that
be
most
familiar
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
at
such
an
hour
as
would
afford
him
time
to
reach
it
a
little
before
sunset
,
he
leave
the
inn
,
and
turn
into
the
busy
street
.
  
<EOS>
He
have
not
go
far
,
and
be
thoughtfully
make
his
way
among
the
noisy
crowd
,
when
he
feel
a
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
,
turn
,
recognise
one
of
the
waiter
from
the
inn
,
who
beg
his
pardon
,
but
he
have
leave
his
sword
behind
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
why
have
you
bring
it
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
ask
,
stretch
out
his
hand
,
and
yet
not
take
it
from
the
man
,
but
look
at
him
in
a
disturbed
and
agitated
manner
.
  
<EOS>
the
man
be
sorry
to
have
disoblige
him
,
and
would
carry
it
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
the
gentleman
have
say
that
he
be
go
a
little
way
into
the
country
,
and
that
he
may
not
return
until
late
.
 
<EOS>
the
road
be
not
very
safe
for
single
traveller
after
dark
;
and
,
since
the
riot
,
gentleman
have
be
more
careful
than
ever
,
not
to
trust
themselves
unarmed
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
think
you
be
a
stranger
,
sir
,
"
he
add
,
"
and
that
you
may
believe
our
road
to
be
well
than
they
be
;
but
perhaps
you
know
them
well
,
and
carry
fire
-
arm
---
"
  
He
take
the
sword
,
and
put
it
up
at
his
side
,
thank
the
man
,
and
resume
his
walk
.
  
<EOS>
It
be
long
remember
that
he
do
this
in
a
manner
so
strange
,
and
with
such
a
tremble
hand
,
that
the
messenger
stand
look
after
his
retreat
figure
,
doubtful
whether
he
ought
not
to
follow
,
and
watch
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
long
remember
that
he
have
be
hear
pace
his
bedroom
in
the
dead
of
the
night
;
that
the
attendant
have
mention
to
each
other
in
the
morning
,
how
fevere
and
how
pale
he
look
;
and
that
when
this
man
go
back
to
the
inn
,
he
tell
a
fellow
-
servant
that
what
he
have
observe
in
this
short
interview
lie
very
heavy
on
his
mind
,
and
that
he
fear
the
gentleman
intend
to
destroy
himself
,
and
would
never
come
back
alive
.
  
<EOS>
with
a
half
-
consciousness
that
his
manner
have
attract
the
man
's
attention
(
remember
the
expression
of
his
face
when
they
part
)
,
Mr
Haredale
quicken
his
step
;
and
arrive
at
a
stand
of
coach
,
bargain
with
the
driver
of
the
good
to
carry
him
so
far
on
his
road
as
the
point
where
the
footway
strike
across
the
field
,
and
to
await
his
return
at
a
house
of
entertainment
which
be
within
a
stone's
-
throw
of
that
place
.
 
<EOS>
arrive
there
in
due
course
,
he
alight
and
pursue
his
way
on
foot
.
  
<EOS>
He
pass
so
near
the
Maypole
,
that
he
could
see
its
smoke
rise
from
among
the
tree
,
while
a

of

---
some
of
its
old
inhabitant
,
doubtless
---
sail
gaily
home
to
roost
,
between
him
and
the
unclouded
sky
.
 
<EOS>
"
the
old
house
will
brighten
up
now
,
"
he
say
,
as
he
look
towards
it
,
"
and
there
will
be
a
merry

beneath
its
ivied

.
 
<EOS>
It
be
some
comfort
to
know
that
everything
will
not
be
blight
hereabouts
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
glad
to
have
one
picture
of
life
and
cheerfulness
to
turn
to
,
in
my
mind
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
resume
his
walk
,
and
bend
his
step
towards
the
Warren
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
a
clear
,
calm
,
silent
evening
,
with
hardly
a
breath
of
wind
to
stir
the
leave
,
or
any

to
break
the
stillness
of
the
time
,
but
drowsy
sheep
-
bell
tinkle
in
the
distance
,
and
,
at
interval
,
the
far
-
off
lowing
of
cattle
,
or

of
village
dog
.
 
<EOS>
the
sky
be
radiant
with
the
soften
glory
of
sunset
;
and
on
the
earth
,
and
in

,
a
deep
repose
prevailed
.
 
<EOS>
at
such
an
hour
,
he
arrive
at
the
deserted
mansion
which
have
be
his
home
so
long
,
and
look
for
the
last

upon
its
blacken

.
  
<EOS>
the
ashe
of
the
common
fire
be
melancholy
thing
,
for
in
them
there
be
an
image
of
death
and
ruin
,
---
of
something
that
have
be
bright
,
and
be
but
dull
,
cold
,
dreary
dust
,
---
with
which
our
nature
force
us
to
sympathise
.
 
<EOS>
how
much
more
sad
the
crumbled
ember
of
a
home
:
<EOS>
the
cast
down
of
that
great
altar
,
where
the
bad
among
us
sometimes
perform
the
worship
of
the
heart
;
and
where
the
good
have
offer
up
such
sacrifice
,
and
do
such

of
heroism
,
as
,
chronicle
,
would
put
the
proud
temple
of
old
Time
,
with
all
their
vaunt
annal
,
to
the

!
  
<EOS>
He
rouse
himself
from
a
long
train
of
meditation
,
and
walk
slowly
round
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
be
by
this
time
almost
dark
.
  
<EOS>
He
have
nearly
make
the
circuit
of
the
building
,
when
he
utter
a
half

,
start
,

.
 
<EOS>
reclining
,
in
an
easy

,
with
his
back
against
a
tree
,
and
contemplate
the
ruin
with
an
expression
of
pleasure
,
---
a
pleasure
<EOS>
so
keen
that
it
overcome
his
habitual
indolence
and
command
of
feature
,
and
display

utterly
free
from
all
restraint
or
reserve
,
---
before
him
,
on
his
own
ground
,
and
triumph
then
,
as
he
have
triumph
in
every
misfortune
and

of
his
life
,
stand
the
man
whose
presence
,
of
all
mankind
,
in
any

,
and
least
of
all
in
that
,
he
could
the
least
endure
.
  
<EOS>
although
his
blood
so
rise
against
this
man
,
and
his

so
stir
within

,
that
he

strike
him

,
he
put

upon

that
he
pass

without

.
 
<EOS>
yes
,
and
he
would
have
go
on
,
and
not

,
though
to
resist
the

who
pour
such
hot

in
his

,
require

scarcely

achieve
,
if
this

have

:
and
that
,
with

in

which

well

,
and
in

route
all
the
self
-

it
have
be
anguish
---
acute
,

---
to

.
  
<EOS>
all

,

,

,

;
everything

a

can

;
flee

.
 
<EOS>
and

he
say
,

---
far

:
  
<EOS>
"
why

call

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
to

,
"

Chester

,
"
what

odd

,

we

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
strange
?
 
<EOS>
the
most
remarkable
and

in
the

.
 
<EOS>
I
never
ride
in
the
evening
;
I
have

.
 
<EOS>
the

seize
me
,
quite

,
in
the

.
<EOS>
---
how
very

this
be
!
"
<EOS>
---
He
point
,
as

,
to
the

,

raise

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
praise
your
own
work
very

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Sir

let

;

most

;

be
remark

,
"
I

be

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say

,
"
repeat

.
  
<EOS>
"
work
!
"
echo

John
,
look

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mine
!
---
<EOS>
I
beg
your

,
I
really
beg

---
"
  
<EOS>
"
why
,
you
see
,
"
say

,
"
those
wall
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
those

gable
.
 
<EOS>
You
see

where
fire

rage
.
 
<EOS>
You

that
have

.
 
<EOS>
do

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
"
return

,
gently

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I
see
everything
you
speak

,
when
you

,
and
do

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
but

have
expect
---
 
<EOS>
excuse

---
<EOS>
no
,

do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
pull

,
and

with

of

who
,

,
have

,

"
<EOS>

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

rail

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
hear

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
---
"
<EOS>
and
shall
again
,
"

Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall

as

?
 
<EOS>
the

fall
rather

.
 
<EOS>
well
,
---

.
 
<EOS>
but

can

only

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I

,
"

,
"
you

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

have
be

(

)
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
listen
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
while

rail
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
You

to
do
your
work
a
fit

,
but
one
who
in

---

---

,

)

<EOS>
with

,

,
which
tell
again
be

,

set
on
Gashford
to

work
---
this
work
before

now
.
 
<EOS>
with
these

,
and

,

,

,

he
owe

<EOS>
---
I
have

,

---
by

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
I
see

,
"
he
cry
,
abruptly
point
in

,
and

,
"
and
denial
be
a

!
"
  
<EOS>
He
have

;
but

,

Lord

<EOS>
many

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

be

.
  
<EOS>
Gashford

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
ten

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
